indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of Joint Forest Management Committees (JFMC) members trained in climate-resilient Sustainable Land and Ecosystem Management (SLEM) 2. Develop a strategic plan to institutionalize integrated service provision for climate-resilient SLEM 3. Number of ha areas of degraded bamboo forests rehabilitated through community based participatory arrangement thereby enhancing connectivity between relatively undisturbed forest tracts that harbor globally significant biodiversity 4. Percentage increase earnings of about 700 families from involvement in sustainable management of degraded bamboo areas 5. Number of hectares of degraded lands each for energy and fodder planted with fast growing tree/grass species suited to the local environment 6. Increase in average per capita income by at least 20% over the baseline as a result of fodder plantations and its indirect benefits 7. 40 SME business plans based on sustainable harvest and added-value processing of local NTFPs prepared and operationalized 8. Increase in the use of fallow farmlands by at least 20% over the baseline to enhance livelihoods and reduce extensification pressures 9. Learning on best practices and models disseminated within and outside the project villages

baseline.comment: 1.0 2. Existing institutions need to build holistic understanding of climate-resilient SLEM, especially at the village and district level. 3. Bamboo forest areas in the project disrticts are highly degraded due to anthropogenic activities and require local community participation for its restoration. 4. There is limited livelihood opportunities for socio-economic benefits among the local/forest dwelling communities that are directly dependent on forest resources. 5. At the village level, due to degraded common property resources severity of livestock pressure exists on the local forest areas making them vulnerable to degradation. 6. Local communities have limited financial resources to access fodder which is scarce. 7. Livelihood of the local communities based on potential forest resources is extremely low in the project districts and existing SME have constraints in functioning . 8. Fallow land is gradually increasing due to the present practice of agriculture which in turn requires adaptiation of best practices for its revival. 9. In the current mechanism, there are limited opportunities and existing models of sustainable land management for communities to replicate.

target.comment: 1. Conduct Training for 1000 JFMC Members 2. Work towards a strategic plan to institutionalise integrated service provision for Climate Resilient 3. 3500 ha of degraded bamboo forests rehabilitated 4. Increase in earnings of 700 families in the year 5. 50 hectares of degraded lands each planted for energy and fodder 6. Undertake study to assess the increase in per capita income as a result of fodder plantations 7. 40 SME business plans based on sustainable harvest and added-value processing of local NTFPs prepared and operationalized 8. Undertake a study to assess increase in the use of fallow farmlands 9. Develop a best practices document 10. Undertake Mid Term evaluation

actual.comment: 1. Trainings for 1089 JFMC Members completed 2. Agency identified to develop a strategic plan and work initiated 3. 3954 ha of degraded bamboo forests rehabilitated 4. Increase in earnings of 789 families recorded, shows a 40% increase from baseline 5.3,000 hectares of degraded lands each for energy and fodder planted which was an overachievement from the planned targets 6. Study to assess the increase in per capita income as a result of fodder plantations in process by Indian council for forest research and education. 7. 180 SME business plans based on sustainable harvest and added-value processing of local NTFPs prepared and operationalized. The plans are being reviewed by the Government. It is expected that at least 9 with be operational by 2015 8. Study to assess increase in the use of fallow farmlands scheduled for next year 9. Best practices document prepared 10. Mid Term evaluation conducted

target.comment: 1. Conduct Training for another 1000 JFMC Members 2. Finalise the Strategic Plan 3. Another 3500 ha of degraded bamboo forests to be rehabilitated - communities to be trained in Bamboo harvesting 4. Increase in earnings of 700 more families in the year. Increase the earning of existing ones in the project 5. Monitor the 3000 hectares of degraded lands each for energy and fodder planted from year 2014 6. Complete the study to assess the increase in per capita income as a result of fodder plantations 7. Ensure business plans are operationalised 8. The study to assess increase in the use of fallow farmlands to be completed 9. Disseminate best practices document

result.title: Objective
result.description: To promote community-driven sustainable land and ecosystem management at the landscape level through integration of watershed management, joint forest management, and sustainable livelihoods development so as to balance ecological and livelihood needs.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Hectares of land where climate-resilient, SLEM is demonstrated for further replication in other areas

baseline.comment: 0 hectares

target.comment: 3,000 hectares of non-forest land and 14,500 hectares of degraded bamboo areas within forest lands

actual.comment: The physical targets as per the project were already accomplished in 2014. No new areas have been taken up in 2015. The State Bamboo Mission (SBM) is preparing plans for funding new areas for bamboo plantations in the state. The Project Districts have also prepared and submitted plans to the SBM independently for funding. Also, the regular plantations for forestry species all over the state shall cover new areas which may increase by 10-20 times the actual areas covered under the project in 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Overall decrease in trend and/or severity of land degradation as measured by % increase in NPP (Net Primary Productivity) and/ or RUE (Rain Use Efficiency) and associated loss of biodiversity and enhanced forest cover

baseline.comment: Baseline to be measured in Y1

target.comment: 10% increase in NPP and land productivity over baseline at project demonstration sites

actual.comment: The forest cover has been enriched and biodiversity has increased in terms of regeneration of vegetative species not seen when the degraded land was not treated and protected. New MADPS species has been visibly seen growing on the natural forest floor along with sighting of wild fauna not earlier recorded like some bird species, leopards, tigers (in the forest compartments near the PAs in District Chhindwara, Umaria, Madhya Pradesh). The treated bamboo forests have shown growth and increase in quality and quantity of bamboo about 60-70% as compared to a baseline of 10-20% in the girth, size,height of bamboo. The length of the bamboo is also above 5.5 meters and not deformed as earlier found when they were not treated and protected by the beneficiary families.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Reduced threats to forest habitats enhancing survival probabilities of threatened species

baseline.comment: Baseline to be measured in Y1

target.comment: Reduction in threats over baseline

actual.comment: The areas rehabilitated for the degraded bamboo have been immensely enhanced in its vegetative, floral and fauna habitat by involving the community/families towards its well being and protection. The areas of not only bamboo but in general the forest compartments that were prescribed for treatment, protection, co-management by poor families were so well nurtured that very sparse incidences of forest fires, illegal extraction of fire wood, small timber etc, along with conflict for forest resource extraction by the local communities have been reported almost from all the project sites. The indirect ownership of such forest land/sites by local communities have increasingly benefited the natural resources of those areas and allowed further growth and propagation of flora and fauna which earlier had very narrow opportunity to spread and sustain their existence.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Improved forest cover in the project districts

baseline.comment: Baseline to be measured in Y1

target.comment: Improvement by 3-5% over baseline

actual.comment: A continuous trend of value addition towards increased canopy cover, density of species have been reported in the project area. From the samples taken for such studies by authentic government agencies like the Forest Survey of India etc., a 20% trend of increased growth have been reported in the districts barring few like in the eastern flank of Madhya Pradesh such as Singrauli and Sidhi, where possible mining operations for coal etc. have slightly negative impact although measures of compensatory afforestation have not been included in these districts for a final conclusion.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Enhanced carbon sequestration capacity in project demonstration sites

baseline.comment: Baseline to be measured in Y1

target.comment: 10% increase of total system carbon at project demonstration sites

actual.comment: The carbon sequestration capacity of the degraded forest areas have increased immensely over the four years of project interventions. The natural growth and supportive interventions towards promoting forestry and key species survival with the help of the local communities have set a trend for the carbon sequestration capacity of such project sites, wherein at least 40 to 50% increase in the carbon sequestration in those areas have been reported. Indian Space Research organization (ISRO) has chosen two of their national sites for biomass and carbon sequestration study from the project sites of West Betul and West Chhindwara. Although data at present is not shared by ISRO for lack of empirical conclusions from their own study purpose, the technology used to link the sites of those forest types treated under the project have actually raised the interests of scientific institutions like the State Forest Research Institute, Tropical Forest Research Institute etc. to further research on those key issues from the project intervention sites.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Change in proportion of project participants who are living above the poverty line

baseline.comment: Approximately 3% of families in target districts/ villages

actual.comment: Out of the 789 families who have been associated for the direct forestry interventions, the benefits direct and indirect provided in the project tenure has immensely supported their socioeconomic well being. A trend analysis carried out randomly in most of the sites have reflected financial inclusion from this experimental model. An enhanced linkage with government schemes addressing poverty alleviation drivers have been witnessed in the poor communes of the project districts. In terms of inclusive socioeconomic growth patterns, all the beneficiaries of the project have bank accounts where the funds against their involvement in the project activities as remuneration is transferred regularly. The co-finance schemes of the State and the Central Government have benefited their household status and ability towards more economic and livelihood choices. An increase of 50-60% in family incomes from such exemplary efforts have been recorded by the Forest Divisions, staff and officials.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Creation of an enabling environment for climate-resilient, sustainable land and ecosystem management

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of sectoral polices that incorporate SLEM guidelines

baseline.comment: Existing sectoral policies

target.comment: Climate-resilient, biodiversity-friendly, SLEM guidelines integrated into State agriculture, animal husbandry, forest, watershed, and tribal welfare policies by Y5

actual.comment:
Administrative Staff College of India, Hyderabad (ASCI) was finally approved for the sectoral policy analysis in December 2014. Due to procedural formalities and unavoidable circumstances encountered by ASCI, the assignment period is extended till August 2015 to submit the interim draft report based on a field study exercise yet to be carried out by them. The MTR recommendations too advised such a study for the project. The outcome is expected to be submitted once ASCI complete the analysis of the state level policies and the field exercises.
The 789 families in the ten Forest Divisions of the project have been provided an orientation and sensitization towards bamboo harvest management aligning the procedures and methods prescribed by the Madhya Pradesh Forest Department for such activities. A manual on bamboo harvest in local language along with tool kits have been distributed during the training events to the beneficiary families. Experts such as retired foresters have been identified as resource persons and have been hired by the respective Forest Divisions for training and sensitization. Field demos were also provided to the beneficiaries by the resource experts.
As per the need assessment survey completed in 2014, the suggestive modules of the Capacity Building of Forest Committee members were prepared by PMU. The first step was to test those modules with the target groups who generally may be considered as illiterate in terms of their formal education. The first phase of the training covered all the ten Forest Divisions with selected Forest Committee members for a direct training skill approach. The exercise covered on an average 35-40 participants for a two to three day workshop at the field level. The workshops involved the participants for an orientation to build there capacities for further sensitization on forestry, natural resources and other skill based issues to become community master trainers. Since January 2015 since all activities for the project perceived for 2015 has been stopped due to the formal extension of the project period by MoEF&CC, Department of Economic Affairs, therefore, UNDP is yet to complete the final endorsement and release of budget as per AWP 2015. The further CB of the Forest Committee members will commence once the above issues are addressed and completed.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of government staff and CBO representatives trained in climate-resilient SLEM

baseline.comment: Limited

actual.comment: In each Forest Divisions, under the Bamboo harvesting and Management operation trainings in 2014, about 10-15 Department staff along with 60-70 project beneficiaries have been trained. A coverage of about 1000 participants. Similarly, for developing master trainers on CC,biodiversity, forestry issues etc. another 1000 participants trained in the first phase. In other trainings that involve livelihood, agriculture, based intervention another 400-500 such villagers under the project have been trained so far. In all, a human resource base of 2500-3000 Forest Committee members/forest staff etc. have been oriented and trained on various issues that link the project objectives with community skill and knowledge requirements.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Strategic plan to institutionalize integrated service provision for climate-resilient SLEM

baseline.comment: None

target.comment: Plan developed and verified

actual.comment:
ASCI, Hyderabad under the assignment awarded to them will be holding state level workshop to involve the various line departments/agencies/civil societies to integrate the SLEM good practices through the departmental objectives, state level policies to integrate NRM issues. This workshop will be planned by ASCI once their sectoral policy study is completed by August 2015.
Also, Madhya Pradesh Forest Department, has issued state wide circulars to the respective Forest Circles, Divisions to align their local efforts in NRM/Forestry initiatives based on the emerging learning's and opportunities from the project model.
The State bamboo Mission has also converged its objectives and planning modalities in lieu to the project learning's to some extent. SBM has state wide promotion of bamboo, buyer's and seller's meet, community specific strategies towards livelihood through bamboo resources linking the regional, national and global interest groups with potential districts.

baseline.comment:
No such policy amendment was existing to consider families as the beneficiaries instead of laborers during the inception of the project though in 2001-02 such an intervention was implemented by the Forest Department towards involving families for treatment/conservation/protection of Degraded bamboo Forest Areas
THIS BASELINE IS NO LONGER BEING USED.

target.comment:
The Government of Madhya Pradesh may consider the proposal and a revision under the JFM resolution clause, to have families for the entitlement of the usufruct resource from the Degraded bamboo Forest Areas at least in the five project districts through a scientific management and practice for harvesting of bamboo.
THIS BASELINE IS NO LONGER BEING USED.

actual.comment: PMU has submitted a proposal note for amendment in the JFM Resolution of the State to Government of Madhya Pradesh through the Forest Department channel. The proposed request is pending for decision at the government level.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Community-driven, climate-resilient approaches for sustainable land and ecosystem management are demonstrated in 4 micro-catchments

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Approx. 14,500 ha of degraded bamboo forests rehabilitated through community based participatory arrangement, thereby enhancing connectivity between relatively undisturbed forest tracts that harbor globally significant biodiversity

baseline.comment: Highly degraded areas with only 15-20 culms per clump

target.comment: 25-35 culms per clump by Y5

actual.comment: A random analysis of enumeration exercise carried out for rehabilitation of degraded bamboo forests have shown evident presence of very healthy growth of bamboo culms. On an average new culms of 12-15 bamboo have been counted in the project sites barring a few Forest Divisions. The growth promoted over a period of four years have increased the culms by 40-60% in each clump whose radius has been more than 2-3 meters. Per hectare presence of clumps in the degraded bamboo forests are more than 100. An average of 100 per hectare was kept as a baseline for treatment by the beneficiary families. Thus enormous increase not only in numbers but of girth and height etc. also have been recorded. Harvesting unfortunately could not be done in 2014. So far in 2015 also, the community driven extraction as a follow up to the CB exercise on bamboo harvesting could not be done so far. The budget required for the planned activities were restrained because of the clarity on the project extension by the Department of Economic Affairs (DEA), GoI, New Delhi. Thus, the AWP 2015 line of activities have been considerably delayed so far till June 2015 in the absence of funds at PMU level. In the remaining project period, procedural issues and clearances with the Forest Department regarding the harvest and production of bamboo is yet to be sorted out administratively so that the benefit sharing mechanism linking community with the department and the sites is formally acknowledged.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Increase in earnings of about 700 families from involvement in sustainable management of degraded bamboo areas

baseline.comment: About 1000 INR per month/family

target.comment: Increase by 60% by Y5

actual.comment: The earnings of the households belonging to the project beneficiaries have been enhanced by 40% at least. A random sampling to hold interactions with the families have affirmed the household increase in earning as well as the heightened awareness of the members to follow much further skill based training and employment due to the project remuneration support. Given a choice, the model has generated a sustained interest of the community towards livelihood skill development and choices of emerging out of the poverty cycle. An average increase of INR 3000 per family is estimated as an impact assessment of the project on a monthly basis. Since the other additional incomes from seasonal extraction of forest resources, agriculture labor etc. is not added, the minimum increase itself have brought in possibilities of linkage with further education, skill training, health welfare etc.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Degraded lands planted with fast growing tree species suited to the local environment
% of existing head loaders in target villages who substitute their existing practice with income derived from plantations

baseline.comment:
0 hectares
0%

target.comment:
200 hectares by Y5
15% by Y5

actual.comment:
In each district, at least ten times the area covered under the project has been considered in 2014-15 by the Forest Department for plantation activities. The initiatives have been to promote fast growing tree species, local ecologically suited species, timber species etc. A proposal to the Guinness Book of World Record is currently being considered regarding the enormous plantation drive carried out in 2014-15. A very exhaustive data base of the plantation drives capturing each of the districts and Forest Divisions is under preparation and will then be examined by officials from the Guinness Book of World Records. As a sample, if 10 plants have been planted under the project then about 1000 have been planted through other schemes and efforts of the Forest Department n the project districts, thus covering hundreds of hectares of land.
Presently, head loaders at the village level are utilizing the fodder from the project sites for their own house hold consumption and to some extent for sale in the local markets to earn small profits. From the total 200 hectares of fodder plantations, about 250-300 villages have been benefited. The locals have free access to the sites to harvest fodder. On an average, each hectare of fodder site is producing 25-40 tons of fodder annually, which is being harvested by the fellow villagers seasonally. The local department staff has been appreciating the initiative as it has promoted stall feeding of livestocks to some extent and provided a continuous resource base for fodder harvesting to the local communities.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Reduction in fuelwood extraction pressures on surrounding forests attributable to fuelwood plantations
â—¦ Increase in average fodder yields of degraded land
â—¦ Hectares of forest facing pressure for livestock grazing and/ or fodder collection attributable to fodder plantations
â—¦ Increase in perennial vegetation cover on degraded lands

baseline.comment:
Baseline to be identified in Y1 for each demonstration site
Baseline to be identified in Y1 for each demonstration site
Baseline to be identified in Y1 for each demonstration site
Baseline to be identified in Y1 for each demonstration site

target.comment:
Reduction by at least 40%
5075% by Y5
At least 3040% of this area faces decreased pressure by Y5
25-40% increase by Y5

actual.comment:
The project villages have shown an increasing trend to adapt to rural technologies for house hold energy consumptions. One arena to focus is the fuel wood resource use at the house hold level. It has been reduced because of the continuous promotion of bio gas plants, smoke less stoves consuming very less fuel wood etc. It has been dovetailed with various convergence initiatives with other government agencies for promotion of alternative technologies for bio gas and smokeless cook stoves, which reduced consumption of fuel wood. On an estimation, about 80% of the project beneficiaries and their house holds have reported a change process where in acceptance to more environment friendly alternatives are adapted. A very low quantity of fuel wood extraction from nearby forests could be measured case wise. Fodder extraction from project sites has increased by 80%. Annually on an average estimation, about 5000-6000 tons of fodder is being extracted from the sites.
The perennial vegetation cover in the degraded forest lands covered by the project, has witnessed a trend of 50-60% increase. The watershed sites, plantation sites, forest areas protected and management by the local communities have enhanced the growth and cover by many folds. This has mostly benefited the highly degraded forest lands where the extensive pressure of livestock damaged the regeneration of vegetative species.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Number of households in demonstration site directly benefiting from the fodder production component
â—¦ Change in average per capita income as a result of fodder plantations and its indirect benefits
â—¦ Number of SME business plans based on sustainable harvest and added-value processing of local NTFPs
â—¦ Number of SME business plans operationalized

baseline.comment:
No. of households in demonstration site measured in Y1
Baseline to be identified in Y1 for participating families
0
0

target.comment:
At least half of the households benefit
Increase by at least 20% by Y5
100
40

actual.comment:
About 300 villages may have the access of fodder from the sites developed under the project. The average production of 5-6000 tons of fodder over the seasonal cycles have been widely accessed by the villagers. At times the harvest has also been sold locally but it is not of a generous scale monetarily which may add as a continuous source of income for the families. A support mechanism which had fallen back from a village ecosystem may have emerged from the development of these sites under the project. A site specific property resource use has helped further the local degraded forest land to develop and regenerate. About 30-40% increase in the ground level regeneration capacity of the degraded forest lands have been revived due to the fodder development sites.
The 180 business plans under the bio-resource based SMEs have been submitted by the agencies who have been assigned to develop for the respective Forest Divisions. The business plans have been provided to the local Forest Officials to judge for the plan best suited to their interest and resource availability to involve the villagers for the entrepreneurship skill development and managing the SMEs. In 2014-15 five SMEs were identified for implementation in East, West and South Chhindwara Forest Divisions. The DFOs intend to develop self help groups towards women based incense stick and incense preparing SMEs which earlier has recorded a success in Sidhi district. In 2015, all the ten Forest Divisions shall be asked to finalize at least one SME out of the basket of plans prepared for their divisions to implement with the help of the external consultants/agencies for a long term hand holding support.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description:
Number of persons with enhanced capacity to promote livelihood security through sustainable natural resource-based enterprises
â—¦ Curtailment of distress migration
â—¦ Number of women participants in SMEs

baseline.comment:
0
No. of families affected measured in Y1
0

target.comment:
1000
At least 10% of households no longer affected by distress migration by Y5
At least 20% of participants are women

actual.comment: Three agencies selected under the project for development and establishment of SMEs are Access Development Services, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh Vigyan Sabha, Bhopal and Indian Institute of Forest Management, Bhopal. The first two consultant agencies in 2014 have imparted Entrepreneurship Development Trainings in the Forest Divisions of Betul, Chhindwara and Umaria. Each EDP training consisted of 35-40 participants carefully identified and selected by the agency with the support of the Forest Division officials/staff. The 3-5 day trainings had a comprehensive module of approach to the issue of SME based livelihood development. Hands on experiences along with orientation on the bio-resource product to be targeted for the initiative was informed to the participants. About 800 villagers were targeted for the EDP programme. Out of which the agencies will further select the potential villagers to develop their SME based groups for a more detailed training to establish a SME as an outcome of the consultancy. More than 25% participants were targeted women from the villages. One plan with the consent and approval of the DFOs shall be implemented in 2015 in each of the Forest Divisions.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description:
Number of SMEs operationalized under the project that are linked up with local banking institutions for obtaining loans for further expansion
Hectares of community land mobilized for reviving local species that enhance ecosystem health and also generate benefits for landless communities (fuelwood, fodder, medical plants, fruit)

baseline.comment:
0
0 hectares

target.comment:
At least 25% by project end
600 hectares

actual.comment:
At least ten new SMEs are expected to be developed and established by the consultant agencies in collaboration with the DFOs. These new SMEs will be linked over a period of six months to an year of existence, mandatory for their linkages with local banks. The new SMEs are expected to be initiated by the consultants once funds are released to support their work in 2015. By December 2015, a progress of establishing the SMEs is anticipated.
Under Hariyali Mahotsav (Greening of Landscape) drive by the Forest Department, at least 500-600 hectares of forest land has been covered. In the ten Forest Divisions of the project, a resultant impact of about 5000-8000 hectares of forest land has been considered for improving the health of the local ecosystems. It has been four to five times the areas of the project sites. So far during the project period, an estimated, 25000 to 30,000 hectares of such areas have been covered by the department. Large scale plantation drives introducing species best suited to the local ecology have been considered.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description:
Rejuvenation and or renovation of existing community based watershed structures in 40 villages
New watershed structures built based on local needs and available project resources

baseline.comment:
No. of structures in target villages measured in Y1
0

target.comment:
All structures deemed necessary and viable are rejuvenated by Y5
At least 10 by Y5

actual.comment: No new areas or structures have been covered or constructed in the reporting period as the project target has already been fulfilled.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description:
Revival of farmlands that are laying fallow or unused due to lack of water
Increase in farm productivity of marginal and pro-poor tribal farmers due to proposed watershed interventions

baseline.comment:
Area to be measured in Y1
Productivity measured in Y1

target.comment:
At least 20% of farmlands are revived
At least 10% increase by Y5

actual.comment: Under the project, in Sidhi Forest Division, agriculture based initiative was carried out with the help of an expert. About 50 hectares of agriculture land was covered under the initiative where the 2-3 groups comprising about 40 farmers managed to implement bio-dynamic farming. Apart from the above efforts, new interventions were not carried out.

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description:
Number of sectoral polices that incorporate SLEM guidelines - IT IS A DUPLICATED INDICATOR of OUTCOME 1. The correct indicator are:
- WATER USER GROUPS (WUGS) CREATED IN EACH OF THE FOUR PROJECT DISTRICTS
- INCREASE IN THE USE OF FALLOW FARMLANDS TO ENHANCE LIVELIHOODS AND REDUCE EXTENSIFICATION PRESSURES

baseline.comment:
Existing sectoral policies - IT IS A DUPLICATE BASELINE of OUTCOME 1. The correct baseline are :
- NONE
- Area measured in Y1

target.comment:
At least 25
At least 20% increase by Y5

actual.comment:
WUGs by Rajiv Gandhi Watershed Mission were established in the project districts.
An estimated 30% increase due to the interventions of the RGWM may have been attained. The extent of impact by the watershed based initiatives of the mission is not available at present. But the usual annual extent of impact on agriculture due to the watershed based activities may have such an outreach as recorded earlier by the mission.

indicator.title: Indicator 11
indicator.description:
Number of sectoral polices that incorporate SLEM guidelines - IT IS A DUPLICATED INDICATOR of OUTCOME 1. The correct indicator are:
- INCREASE IN ORGANIC AND TRADITIONAL INNOVATIONS FOR RAIN FED FARMING
- CHANGE IN ON FARM PRODUCTIVITY THROUGH USE OF IMPROVED SEED VARIETIES

baseline.comment:
Existing sectoral policies - IT IS A DUPLICATED BASELINE of OUTCOME 1. The correct baseline are:
- CURRENT USE MEASURED IN Y1
- FARM PRODUCTIVITY MEASURED IN Y1

target.comment:
Increased by at least 30% by Y5
Increase by at least 15% by Y5

actual.comment:
The Government of Madhya Pradesh since 2014 has extensively promoted the organic agriculture drive in the state. The emphasis is on small and marginal farmers for organic farming and special incentives towards the value chain benefits also has been assured. The outreach of the state policy to address the initiative has impacted at least 20-30% of the small farmers of the state. Improved seed varieties, technological innovations for organic farming, buyer/seller meet at various points of agriculture business centers have been organized. Large scale training of developing organic seed varieties and efforts to introduce these varieties in the farming practices in the state has been initiated. In each district of the state, knowledge centers for organic farming has been created for sensitizing the farmers.
Highly subsidized efforts for promoting drip irrigation practices amongst farmers has been promoted. The project area has also been covered to support the small and marginal farmers. Innovative technological tools and implements, seed varieties, organic fertilizers in large scale measures provided and centers established for better access by such farmers towards organic farming and drip irrigation based rain fed farming practices.
The agriculture Mandi (trading hubs of local agri produce) have been restructured for better accommodation of the policy shift of the government to help small farmers under these drives.
An impact of good quality seed has improved the farm productivity by 25% in the state. The small farmers feel confident on organic horticulture produce which has increased its market share in the state by 30 to 40% as a part of the national value chain. It has increased the earnings of the small farmers by 20%.

indicator.title: Indicator 12
indicator.description: Reduction in natural resource dependency of farmers on near by forests attributable to integration of on farm agro-forestry practices

baseline.comment: Extent of pressure imposed by farmers measured in Y1

target.comment: Reduction of at least 20% by Y5

actual.comment: A reduction of 25% on forest due to the ongoing promotion of farm and agro-forestry initiatives has been anticipated. Like in case of the State bamboo Mission, it has increasingly promoted bamboo plantations on agriculture and community lands over the years. The small farmers in the project districts covering even the bamboo beneficiaries have been targeted for such a drive. The farm/agro forestry activities has at present prepared the ground work to make villagers participate in the drive. Various silvi pastoral models, along with agrarian produce is helping the farmers to opt for their needs from the farmlands rather than the local forests barely existing with disappearing resources.

indicator.title: Indicator 13
indicator.description: Improvements in soil fertility

baseline.comment: Fertility on demonstration sites measured in Y1

target.comment: Increase by at least 5%

actual.comment: The soil fertility of forest plantation sites have been sustained to improve further. The change is not varying much from last years estimation. The vegetative growth patterns in these areas have indicated the enrichment of soil as new species or dormant root stocks are propagating now. Similarly, an increase of soil fertility in agriculture land has been observed. About 30% of farmers involved in the agri initiatives have addressed improvement of soil fertility by 40%. This has been so due to the involvement of various innovative practices where organic, bio-composting, yeast culture based rejuvenation of soil etc. has been carried out on a pilot basis.

indicator.title: Indicator 14
indicator.description: Number of sectoral polices that incorporate SLEM guidelines - THIS INDICATOR IS NO LONGER TO BE USED. IT IS A DUPLICATED INDICATOR of OUTCOME 1.

baseline.comment: Existing sectoral policies - THIS BASELINE IS NO LONGER TO BE USED. IT IS A DUPLICATED BASELINE of OUTCOME 1.

target.comment: At least two policies - NO LONGER TO BE USED, DUPLICATED WITH OUTCOME 1

actual.comment: N/A

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Capacities for adaptive management, learning and replication of project lessons are developed

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Local level monitoring mechanisms set up in each project site (CBIA)

baseline.comment: None

target.comment: Established in each demonstration site by end of Y2

actual.comment: It has been decided to select a compteent agency/ expert firm to carry out the socioeconomic study and biodiversity assessment under the project. PMU has prepared a document for inviting proposals from competent agencies nationally for this study. An agency which has experience and competency to do so will now be selected in 2015. Once these studies are completed, the DFOs may have a guideline of establishing the local monitoring centers. These may then act as a community sustained and driven center towards self assessment of priorities at the local level.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Learning on best practices and models disseminated within and outside the project villages

baseline.comment: None

target.comment: Documentation is available in local languages by Y5

actual.comment: A collaborative documentation has been carried out in 2014 by the ICFRE, Dehradun SLEM Technical Facilitation Organization. A short film documentation on the Chhindwara district and a national level best practices book was published by ICFRE where the project successes has also been documented.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Number of sectoral polices that incorporate SLEM guidelines - IT IS A DUPLICATED INDICATOR of OUTCOME 1. The correct indicator is:
REPLICATION PLAN

baseline.comment: Existing sectoral policies - IT IS A DUPLICATED BASELINE of OUTCOME 1. The correct baseline is : NONE

target.comment: Agreement, by Y5, on watersheds/ villages where lessons can be replicated in 5 and 10 year increments after project closure

actual.comment: As a replication plan, the Madhya Pradesh Forest Department issued circulars for the state wide Forest Circles and Forest Divisions to adopt the project model for natural resource rehabilitation in the future. The community group based bamboo model for treatment, protection and ecosystem regeneration has been instructed through the circulars. In the government schemes like the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment guarantee Act (MNREGA) etc. The state wide consideration for community based forest restoration work etc. is proposed in working out strategies of interventions. Such initiatives may maximize the involvement of local poor families as a year long approach to employment vis a vis rehabilitation of local ecosystems.

4. Undertake revision of Malvan Marine Sanctuary Management Plan 5. Number of Workshops on Landscape conserving coastal and Marine Diversity organized 6. Number of exposure visits in and outside India organized 7. Number of National and International avenues utilized to share project achievements

result.title: Objective
result.description: To mainstream biodiversity conservation considerations into those production sectors that impact coastal and marine ecosystems of the SCME.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Landscape/seascape area in the SCME where production activities mainstream biodiversity conservation

baseline.comment: 0 ha

target.comment: About 6,327 sq. km. (2,327 sq km as area of direct influence and 4,000 sq km as area of indirect influence)

actual.comment: Recruitment of LP consultant in process, micro-plans of 134 project villages and fisheries plan; tourism plan prepared and proposal for MPA in the sea scape of Angria Bank under preparation. A project on Solid waste management is under implementation by Malvan Municipal Authorities and Kunkeshwar Village level authorities. The Sindhudurg Fort has been declared Plastic Free. Turtle nests have been conserved during the nesting period (November 2014-May 2015). Mangrove Gene Bank project on raising RET species has been sanctioned.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Extent of coral reefs in the project area

baseline.comment: 360 sq.km and this will be verified in first 6 months of the project

target.comment: The extent of coral cover remains at least stable or increasing.

actual.comment:
Following achievements made in respect of Coral conservation:
1. Studies on Coral and Associated species of Sindhudurg by the Zoological Survey of India: i. Species recorded: Corals-14 species, Molluscs-16 species, Echinoderms- 3 species, Crustaceans -12 sp, Polychaetes- 3 sp, Fishes - 38 sp, Seaweeds- 7 sp.
ii. Permanent plots marked.
iii. New genus of Corals, viz., Pavona bipartita, and Goniopora minor, have been identified.
2. Exploration of Angria Bank: approx. 100 species have been identified during the first expedition. Based on the findings of the study, it has been proposed to declare a Marine Reserve in the area covering a submerged plateau of 700 Sq. Km.
3. Setting up of Artificial Reef and Coral transplantation in an area of 0.25 Sq. km. area along Sindhudurg coast has been initiated.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Population status of following critical species: Olive Ridley turtle and Indo-pacific hunch back dolphin

baseline.comment: 40-50 nesting sites of Olive Ridley Turtles reported and 100-150 Indo-pacific hump back dolphins frequent the region. This will be verified in first 6 months of the project

target.comment: Population status remain at least stable/ increasing

actual.comment:
On-shore Turtle Conservation undertaken and the results of the interventions are summarized as under:
Year 2014-15 Sites conserved 13
Nests conserved 35
Hatchling released 2164
Turtle conservation: 108 nests (36+38+34) have been protected during project period from around 16 sites with the active participation of local communities
Project has been awarded to Konkan Cetacean research Team(KCRT). The assessment of the research team indicates presence of Indo-pacific humpback dolphin in the range of 455-569 and that of Finless porpoises in the range of 65-130.
A reporting system for stranding and beaching has been developed.
Capacity building program: 3 programs: 52 individual trained representing departments of fisheries, forest, port, animal husbandry and 3 programs for locals where in 87 person trained

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Population status of birds (including migratory):

baseline.comment: This will be verified in first one year of the project

target.comment: Population status remains at least stable or increases.

actual.comment:
Implementing agency: Salim Ali Centre for Ornithology and Natural History (SACON)through their assessment have recorded the following:
200 individuals species
73 wetland dependent species
25-30 thousand mixed species flock of gulls.
11 nests of White-bellied Seas-Eagle.
5 nature trails.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Cross-sectoral planning framework that mainstreams biodiversity conservation considerations

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Landscape level zoning plan (LP) that zones resource use by taking into account conservation needs of the SCME

target.comment: 1 Landscape Plan that prepared and integrated with the District level planning process

actual.comment:
EOIs have been floated thrice and no suitable agencies could be shortlisted. This is because landscape level plans for coastal and marine biodiversity conservation is a relatively new concept in India and there is limited or no precedent of such initiatives. New strategies for identifying agencies are being worked out through a consultative process. This matter has been taken up to NPSC and SPSC.
Cross Sectoral Stakeholder Consultation Committee (CSSCC) formation has already taken place

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Establishing a functional cross-sectoral Stakeholder Committee for the management of SCME involving District Planning Dept, Forest Dept, the Maritime Board, Dept. of Industries, Fisheries, Agriculture, Tourism, Private Sector & NGOs

actual.comment:
Cross sectoral stakeholder committee constituted vide Go No WLP-1009/CR17/-1. Dated 20 August 2013.
Three meeting conducted during from 2014-2015 which is listed below:
1. 30th July 2014
2. 12th January 2015
3. 5th May 2015

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Recommendations on reform of Wildlife (Protection) Act

baseline.comment: WPA has a terrestrial focus that is not suited to marine PAs

target.comment: Amendments that give explicit recognition to marine PAs are approved or under consideration by the MoEF

actual.comment:
Government notification is awaited.
Proposal sent to Government of Maharashtra for transfer of power to Fisheries Department for enforcing the provisions of the Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972.
Joint patrolling exercise of forest department and fisheries department is being implemented.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Recommendations on reform of MFRA

baseline.comment: MFRA does not adequately incorporate the integration of the conservation of coastal and marine biodiversity

target.comment: Amendments to MFRA incorporating provisions for the conservation of coastal and marine biodiversity approved or under consideration by State Department of Agriculture/ Fisheries

actual.comment:
The Commissioner of Fisheries, Government of Maharashtra has made it mandatory to use square mesh at cod end of Trawl nets.
Restriction of vessel size CPUE is under consideration by Government of Maharashtra.
In order to deal with issues of interstate nature, a national fisheries Consultation has been planned to review the marine fisheries regulations of the coastal states in this regard during 2015. Due to Lok Sabha & State Assembly elections during 2014, this workshop could not be conducted as planned

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Compliance of new developments related to tourism, fisheries, ports, mining and agricultural activity in the target landscape with the LP

baseline.comment: There is no comprehensive zoning plan for production activities in the SCME that takes into account conservation needs

target.comment: By project end any new developments related to tourism, fisheries, ports, mining and agricultural activity conform with the LP

actual.comment:
Tourism:
As the Local District administration has already prepared the District Tourism Plan, the activities of the tourism sector under the project has been revised to address the existing gaps in the district tourism plan, which includes, i. Green rating of B&B units, ii. Model for community based tourism of two villages, iii. Alternate tourism destinations to reduce pressure in Malvan, iv. Deal with solid waste generation on the beaches by tourists, v. Anchorage points for boats ferrying tourists to coral areas for snorkeling & diving and vi. Training of snorkeling guides in safety, first-aid & marine life interpretation. The community based tourism plans of two villages and Green Rating of B&B units were prepared by Ms Cultural Aangan and reports in this regard was submitted. The same has been taken up with MTDC for implementation. Proposals for alternative tourism was sought and the same are being finalized. Anchorage point finalization with community and MMB is being initiated.
Agriculture:
System of Rice Intensification (SRI) Phase 3 has been sanctioned which will cover 1000 Acers of Paddy area and 4000 farmers.
Fisheries:
i. Fisheries sector plan prepared.
ii. Acceptance of square mesh at cod end of trawl nets by local fisher’s community.
iii. Improvement of fish stock through artificial reef is under implementation.
iv. Joint patrolling of Sindhudurg by fisheries and Forest Dept. being implemented

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Compliance of existing activities related to tourism, fisheries, ports, mining and agricultural activity in the target landscape with the LP

baseline.comment: There is no comprehensive zoning plan for production activities in the SCME that takes into account conservation needs

target.comment: By project end an action plan for bringing existing activities related to tourism, fisheries, ports, mining and agricultural activity in line with the LP is developed and approved by sectoral departments

actual.comment:
Tourism:
i. Solid waste management programs initiated at Malvan Nagar Parishad and Kunkeshwar Village Panchayat.
ii. Sindhudurg Fort has been made ‘Plastic Free’.
Fisheries:
v. Fisheries sector plan prepared.
vi. Acceptance of square mesh at cod end of trawl nets by local fisher’s community.
vii. Improvement of fish stock through artificial reef is under implementation.
viii. Joint patrolling of Sindhudurg by fisheries and Forest Dept. being implemented.
Agriculture:
i. SRI has been adopted by 235 farmers
ii. System of Rice Intensification (SRI) Phase 3 has been sanctioned which will cover 1000 Acers of Paddy area and 4000 farmers.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Zoning of MMS in line with LP

baseline.comment: Current MMS boundaries do not capture key biodiversity rich areas and there is conflict with local fishermen on resource use issues

target.comment: MMS boundaries and zoning are rationalized to accord protection to biodiversity rich areas and to guarantee occupational interests and innocent passage of local fishers

actual.comment: Several studies for profiling the key biodiversity elements of the SCME covering, Corals & Associated flora & fauna, Cetaceans, Avifauna, Mangroves, Turtles etc. have been initiated. The outcome of these studies wills assist in rationalizing the boundaries and Zoning of MMS. 2. Several meetings have been conducted for discussion with the local communities. After setting up of the interpretation centre and the Foundation the issues relating to the rationalizing of MMS will be taken up.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Financial sustainability strategy for continued implementation of landscape-level management of SCME

actual.comment: The Draft Proposal for formation of the Sindhudurg Foundation has been prepared by LLPMU and submitted to the CSSCC and circulated to the members for comments.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Enhanced capacity of sector institutions for implementing biodiversity-friendly fisheries management plan, ecotourism management plan and MMS management plan

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of representatives from the key sectors (government and private) trained in mainstreaming and integration of environmental management considerations and safeguards into policies, plans and activities of key sectors

target.comment: Production sector: 1 000 Conservation sector: 100 Livelihood sector: 5 000

actual.comment:
Male Female Total
1. Capacity building: 930 460 1390
2. Awareness: 571 57 628*
3. Meetings: 268 111 379
* In addition to 3 Clean beach programmes=8700 participants
Conservation Sector:
4. Cetacean stranding and beaching:
3 programs: 52 individual trained representing departments of fisheries, forest, port, animal husbandry and 3 programs for locals where in 88 person trained.

23 officials of forest departments, 3 women: 20 men.
1 program, 15 men, 22 women,37 local trained

CURRICULA – The following publications brought out:

Livelihood:

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Mesh size laws are followed by the trawlers

baseline.comment: To be collected in the first year

target.comment: 50% of trawlers follow the mesh size norms set up by Mesh Regulation Committee, 1983

actual.comment:
1.Baseline results shows 100% non-compliance of mesh size regulations, by the trawlers in Sindhudurg.
2.Commissioner Fisheries, Maharashtra has issued order to make BRJFEDs mandatory on trawlers so that only those who have nets with BRJFEDs are eligible for diesel subsidies. 3. The trials on Square mesh net at the cod end of trawl nets have found wide acceptance among trawler owners in Sindhudurg. As a result of which, under the program, 200 trawlers would be provided square mesh net.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Incidence of encroachment of intensive fishing operations into traditional fishing grounds

baseline.comment: Encroachment is taking place

target.comment: By project end, all fishing activity complies with zoning specified in LP and there are no reports of encroachment

actual.comment:
Joint patrolling of Sindhudurg Coast by Fisheries and Forest Department has been sanctioned and is being implemented.
National Fisheries Meet of the coastal states is being planned

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Reduction/ elimination of trawlers from outside SCME i.e., from Ratnagiri (Maharashtra), Goa and Karnataka

baseline.comment: Baseline to be collected in Year 1

target.comment: 50% reduction of trawlers from outside SCME

actual.comment:
National Fisheries Meet of the coastal states is being planned.
Joint patrolling of Sindhudurg Coast by Fisheries and Forest Department has been sanctioned and is being implemented.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Community based ecotourism operations as a % of all tourism operations in project area

target.comment: 50% by project end

actual.comment:
Guidelines for ecotourism
Green rating for Bed & breakfast units has been prepared.
Panchayats with ecotourism potential identified, need assessed and following support rendered for 12 Gazebos (in 4 villages); 16 paddle boats (in 2 villages); 19 changing room (in 6 villages); 8 mobile toilets (in 3 villages); and water harvesting structures for 2 villages.
Proposals for alternative tourism potential and community based tourism are being considered for finalization

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of violations of MMS Management Plan, compared with year of initial patrolling

baseline.comment: Baseline violations to be measured in 1st 3 months of project

target.comment: Declines by 50% by year 5

actual.comment: In view of the prevailing situation relating to non-acceptance of the MMS, any compliance in this regard would happen after rationalization of the MMS boundaries and Zoning based on findings of the studies being conducted, landscape level planning exercise and consultations with local communities.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Sustainable community livelihoods and natural resource use in the SCME

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Traditional fishing communities continue to practice sustainable, low-impact, traditional fishing activity as measured by extent of rampani fishing and related cooperatives

baseline.comment: 98 rampan fishing units

target.comment: 50% increase

actual.comment: The proposed Joint patrolling exercise is likely to reduce incursion of mechanized fishing boats within 10 fathom limit earmarked for non-mechanized fishing units.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of EDCs active in the SCME

actual.comment:
Project has been awarded to Maharashtra State Biodiversity Board to form 50 BMCs and 50 PBRs,
15 BMCs have already been formed and 17 BMCs are under consideration.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of skills-development activities carried out for VLIs and other local institutions for alternative livelihoods or sustainable ecosystem-based livelihoods that reduce pressures on biodiversity

target.comment: Target to be defined after design of the micro-plans

actual.comment:

The data analysis initiated under the project to benchmark has been completed. The benchmarks of Energy Performance Index for various categories of buildings in different climatic zones are under finalization.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthened institutional capacities at various levels on the strengthened to enactment and enforcement of ECBC for commercial buildings

actual.comment:
4 states have made ECBC compliance mandatory. These states are Rajasthan, AP, Karnataka & Punjab
9 states/Union Territories have notified ECBC within their building bye-laws. These states are, Rajasthan, Odisha, Uttarakhand, UT of Puducherry, AP, Punjab and Karnataka.
ECBC Cells are proposed in 12 states. These states are Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, West Bengal, Bihar, Himachal Pradesh, Haryana, Madhya Pradesh and Delhi.
ECBC Cell in the Uttar Pradesh State Designated Agency (UPNEDA – Uttar Pradesh Nonconventional Energy Development Agency) has been established. ECBC Cells in Chhattisgarh and Karnataka are in their advanced stages of establishment.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of buildings covered in commercial buildings database by Year 2014

actual.comment: The data from 1155 commercial buildings in 6 categories of building in 5 agro climatic regions was collected. A software-based buildings registry has also been developed. Further public and private buildings have been covered. The distribution of data gathered has been presented in table below. These will be analyzed and presented in the following reporting period.

indicator.description: Number of accredited local authorities (at municipality level) to validate and verify mandatory commercial buildings compliance with the ECBC by EOP

baseline.comment: NA

actual.comment:
40 Master trainers trained during reporting period. Cumulative number is 59.
A master trainer is trained on Building Physics, ECBC basics, ECBC advanced calculations for 3 days. This is followed by an exam. They are trained in one of the 3 master training institutes: IIIT Hyderabad, CEPT Ahmedabad, MNIT Jaipur. The successful trainers are provided a certificate by BEE. Further, to institutionalize ECBC training activities in each state, the SDA is supported by the project to engage with a local institute. The project has helped develop the following partnerships: [i] Administrative Staff College of India in Andhra Pradesh, [ii] Rachna Sansad Institute of Architecture in Maharashtra, [iii] Energy Management Centre in Kerala, and [iv] Ela green Buildings & Infrastructure Consultants in Chhattisgarh.

iati-activity.description: The project aims at improving energy efficiency (EE) in the Indian Railways system (and thereby reducing GHG emissions) by removing some of the key barriers that prevent the wide adoption of energy efficiency technologies and measures in the IR system.

result.title: goal
result.description: Reduction of GHG emissions in the Indian Railways System (IRS)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Cumulative emission reductions achieved in the IRS by EOP (million t CO2)

actual.comment:
Feeding, collection and compilation of non-traction energy consumption data for all the Zonal Railways for the year 2011-12, 2012-13 and 2014-14 is completed and uploaded on the website www.railsaver.gov.in
Uploading of data pertaining to Traction distribution and workshop has completed for 17 locations covering 11 zonal railways and for 4 workshops covering 2 divisions.
In addition, the sub-projects/ interventions as identified in the project shall be able to give results for energy saving of 0.0142 million kWh equivalent to 0.117 million t CO2 per year.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Removal of key barriers that prevent the wide adoption of energy efficiency technologies and measures in the IRS

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Total direct energy savings by EOP (billion kWh)

actual.comment:
1. Institutional Barrier
a. TIRFAD is set up at RDSO to collect & disseminate relevant information & provide technical back up to implement EE technologies.
b. Center of Excellence is set up at IRIEEN, Nasik has improved the existing training and testing facilities to have the proper equipment to test the EE technologies & train IR staff and officials on energy efficiency.
2. Information and capacity barriers
A web-portal www.railsaver.in has been developed to access information & data on energy consumption for non traction, traction and workshops over entire Indian Railways system. An agency was hired to analyse Energy Efficiency opportunities in traction and non traction operation. A report prepared by the agency is planned this year to be disseminated by Min of Railways.
3. Incentive Barrier
The energy consumption data from the web portal is being analyzed facilitating planning, procurement decisions and targeted savings at zonal level and Min of Railways.
4. Technology Barrier
An energy lab is being set up at IRIEEN. It shall help in setting up the procedures for testing of electrical equipment’s.
5. Financial Barrier
The steps implemented for the above barriers shall assist in controlling the expenditure on energy consumption and energy consuming products/ equipment’s.
In addition, the sub-projects/ interventions as identified in the project shall be able to give results for energy saving of 0.0173 million kWh equivalent to 0.117 million t CO2 per year.

result.title: Outcome 1.1
result.description: Strengthened IR institutional capacity

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Status report of targeted EE technologies / measures, its availability in India/abroad and gap analysis for its implementation
Established and functioning of EE Centre of Excellence (COE) in IRS by EOP
TIRFAD established and functioning by EOP
COE website established and operational by EOP

actual.comment:
1. Defined the gaps present and to analyze these gaps to define focus areas for the implementation of EE technologies and measures
2. Identified and documented ‘best practices on energy efficiency benchmarks which are feasible in the context of Indian Railways.
3. Established specific EE benchmarks for the Indian Railways System (IRS).
4. Reviewed existing energy efficiency technologies and measures that have proven to be successful in India (either in IR or in other sectors) and definition of EE benchmarks
5. Prioritized energy efficiency technologies and measures to be implemented
6. Documented EE technologies e.g. standards, code of practices. M&W specifications, test procedures, installations & testing checklists, etc.
7. Identified energy intensive departments, segments, and units
8. Reviewed existing incentive and award schemes, both within and outside India for Railway operations precisely in India
COE has been set up at Indian Railway Institute for Electrical Engineers (IRIEEN),Nasik and working since Oct’13. IRIEEN shall award the work by Sept’14 for energy lab set up and for preparing CBT modules to provide web based training on energy efficiency to the railway officials.
Technology Information Resource and Facilitation Desk (TIRFAD) is set up at RDSO, Lucknow and working since October’2014. TIRFAD was assigned the work for development of energy audit manual, development of specification for hiring energy efficiency services, contract procedures (technical and financial standards) for procuring energy efficiency services. Two documents were finalized on development of energy audit guidelines and contract procedures. Other work shall be completed by Aug’2015.
Website established and operational since April’ 2014. Data pertaining to Non traction energy consumption and other equipment’s is completed and uploaded on the web portal. Uploading of data pertaining to Traction distribution and workshop has commenced and completed for 17 locations covering 11 zonal railways and for 4 workshops covering 2 divisions
CBT modules are being prepared to provide web based training to the officers over Indian Railways. IRIEEN is developing the testing capacity while Zonal Training Schools (ZTS) in each railways.
6 courses each of 2 weeks duration by National Productivity Council on Energy Audit.
