result.title: Objective
result.description: To mainstream coastal and marine biodiversity conservation into production sectors in the East Godavari River Estuarine Ecosystem (EGREE)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Landscape/seascape area in the EGREE where production activities mainstream biodiversity conservation

baseline.comment: 0 ha

target.comment: About 80,000 ha (46,450 ha as area of direct influence and 33,550 ha as area of indirect influence)

actual.comment:
Within the reporting period, the project activities have directly influenced about 45,000 ha. The detailed activities are elaborated below:
A. Increased level of protection of Mangroves and other habitats and enforcement in association with Coast Guard, Navy and Fisheries Department, B. Improvement of the existing mangrove habitat by mangrove plantations of 60 acres during the reporting period, C. Marine Turtle National Workshop was organized for reviving turtle conservation networks in the eastern coastal states of India. Training on turtle stranding for preventing turtle deaths was carried out and an Action Plan for the East Coast States of India was also discussed. The outcomes of all the recommendations was compiled into a Vizag Declaration for conservation of Marine Turtles in India . Preliminary proceedings cum action plan was done and detailed proceedings under preparation, D. Promoting Community Based Eco-Tourism in and around Coringa Wildlife Sanctuary and adjoining Reserve Forest areas, E. Coastal beach cleanup programmemes involving Coast Guard, Marine Police, youth, local schools, colleges and industries. F. Strengthening of enforcement departments (Coast Guard, Marine Police, Fisheries, Forest Departments etc) for conserving the biodiversity of EGREE region through joint monitoring programme. G. Involving Corporate Sectors in Coastal and Marine Biodiversity Conservation
H. Biodiversity conservation programmes were conducted for 75 Nature clubs in local schools and colleges to increase the awareness levels among the students through Wildlife Week Celebrations, International Coastal Cleanup Day, and Exhibitions & Workshops, Biodiversity Day celebrations etc. I. CBOs, EDCs, VSS, SHGs further strengthened for mangrove protection and conservation and J. Promotion of alternative livelihoods for reducing dependency on forests through training to youth groups on Eco-Tourism based Nature-Guide, Hospitality management and Cookery. SMART programme for village girls and women on apparel training and designing center in collaboration with ATDC, Hyderabad.
2. Approximately 28,000 ha area was indirectly influenced during the reporting period through the following:
A. Awareness programmes, B. Setting up of awareness hoardings (30) all around the EGREE Region, C. Increased Knowledge levels of stakeholders through publications viz. booklets (1), book (1), brochures (7), posters (7), handouts (2), standees (20), D. Increased awareness through Kalajatha Programmes (60) (similar to street play); and E. 1st time in India presented the urgent need to mitigate human wildlife conflict between fishing cat and fisherman and also between otters and fisherman/aquaculture farmers with appropriate statistics at National government level.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Percentage of allocation of CSR expenditures of production sectors aligned with landscape-level Strategic Plan for the EGREE

baseline.comment: Limited link with biodiversity conservation objectives

target.comment: At least 50% of the CSR budget of production sectors aligned with biodiversity conservation and sustainable livelihoods objectives at the landscape level

actual.comment: 1. Due to the UNDP/GEF Godavari Project’s initiatives in the EGREE Region for the past three years, around 31% of the CSR budget of production sectors is now aligned for biodiversity conservation and enhancing sustainable livelihood programmes to communities. 2. Corporates like Coromandel International Ltd., Reliance Foundation, GMR Foundation, Cairn Energy, ONGC, GSPC etc have approached the GODAVARI Project team for seeking appropriate programmes like livelihood enhancement, village development, mangrove restoration, massive awareness programmes etc. towards which they can allocate their CSR funds. 3. The Corporte sectors supported for the following awareness programmes / campaigns like World Biodiversity day, Wildlife Week Celebrations, Bio-Andhra, Beach Festival- 2015, Exhibitions & Workshops which are the initiatives of GoI-UNDP-GEF-GoAP GODAVARI Project in collaboration with APFD, Godavari Knowledge Park, Jana Vignana Vedika, PR Govt. College, APTDC during this reporting period. 4. Coromandel International Ltd. has approached EGREE Foundation for providing support to establish about 80 acres of plantation. With their support, over 700 birds were rescued during HudHud cyclone and provided medical care and support till they were able to fly. The APPCB also directed Coromandel International Ltd. to consult EGREE Foundation regarding plantation related issues. Action plans were accordingly designed and executed in the field. 5. Reliance Foundation has assured support for livelihood development programmes initiated by GoI-UNDP-GEF-GoAP GODAVARI Project in the following villages viz. Gadimoga, Chinnavalasala, Peddavalasala and Lakshmipathi Puram. 6. Confederation of Indian Industries (CII), Hyderabad has promised to deploy a person to support further mainstreaming of coastal and marine biodiversity conservation initiatives proposed in the sectoral plan into production sectors.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Improvement in Total Capacity Development Scorecard

actual.comment: Will be evaluated in the Terminal Evaluation.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Population size of following critical species remains stable or increases:
Scyphiphora hydrophyllacea (IUCN threatened)
Olive Ridley turtle (IUCN vulnerable status)
Fishing cat (IUCN status is endangered)

baseline.comment:
Scyphiphora hydrophyllacea: 70 numbers
Olive Ridley Turtle: 300 annually
Fishing cat: 112 as per 2001 census

target.comment:
Population size stable/ increasing as follows:
Scyphiphora hydrophyllacea (increase)
Olive Ridley turtle (stability)
Fishing cat (at least stable or increase)

actual.comment: 1. Scyphiphora hydrophyllacea is Stable; 2. Nesting habitats of the Olive Ridley Turtle both at Sacramento and Hope Island were protected between January and May. The four year hatching success rate shows more or less a stabilized nestings. But nesting vs hatching ratio has increased from 91.41 % in 2013 to 93% in 2014 and 2015. No. of Nesting females have also increased from 439 in 2014 to 571 in 2015; 3. Population of Fishing Cat and Indian Smooth Coated Otter are monitored through direct sighting, camera traps and indirect sign surveys which indicated that the numbers is stable. Intensive Grid Level Surveys are being carried out to understand behavior pattern of these animals. Village level surveys being carried out to address the conservation issues and sensitize villages towards conservation of these animals. and 4. The MTR suggested renaming this indicator as Red Data Index, instead of species specific indicators.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Population size of birds (including migratory) remains stable or increases:

baseline.comment: Baseline to be collected in Year 1

target.comment: Population size remains at least stable or increases.

actual.comment: 1. The waterbird population in the EGREE region has been estimated in the entire landscape/seascape/coastline with the support of this project and the population is found to be 36,786 birds comprising of 266 species. This is an approximately 2% increase from that of previous year’s population; AND 2. The GODAVARI Project initiative helped in recording 16 new bird species between January 2012 and June 2015 from the EGREE region. The publication “Waterbirds of EGREE” book was published by the project team, which includes the current status of 131 waterbird species recorded in EGREE Region.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: % of open (degraded) mangrove areas in the project area reduced to the minimum

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Sectoral planning in the EGREE mainstreams biodiversity conservation considerations

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Establishment of cross-sectoral institutional mechanism with representation from conservation, livelihood and production sectors

actual.comment: 1. EGREE Foundation – a cross-sectoral institutional mechanism (an initiative of GoI-UNDP-GEF-GoAP Godavari Project) has been established under the Andhra Pradesh Societies Registration act 2001; 2. The Governing Board of the Foundation was established by the. State Government G.O M.S. No. 68 dated 14.08.2014, Organized 1st Governing Board Meeting on 30th October, 2014; 3. The MTR suggested that a District level committee has to be constituted for closer monitoring and can assist the Governing Board effectively. MTR also suggested to avoid incorporation of private/industry members in the EGREE Foundation as it may impact the unbiased functioning and successful implementation of the long term objectives of the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Improvement in Systemic Level Indicators of Capacity Development Scorecard

baseline.comment:
SYSTEMIC LEVEL
1. Capacity to conceptualize and formulate policies, legislations, strategies, programme 67%
2. Capacity to implement policies, legislation, strategies and programmes 33%
3. Capacity to engage and build consensus among all stakeholders 17%
4. Capacity to mobilize information and knowledge 33%
5. Capacity to monitor, evaluate and report and learn at the sector and project levels 33%

target.comment:
SYSTEMIC LEVEL B/L Tgt.
1. Capacity to conceptualize and formulate policies, legislations, strategies, programme 100%
2. Capacity to implement policies, legislation, strategies and programmes 100%
3. Capacity to engage and build consensus among all stakeholders 83%
4. Capacity to mobilize information and knowledge 100%
5. Capacity to monitor, evaluate and report and learn at the sector and project levels 100%

actual.comment:
SYSTEMIC LEVEL as per MTR
1. Capacity to conceptualize and formulate policies, legislations, strategies, programme 0%
2. Capacity to implement policies, legislation, strategies and programmes 33%
3. Capacity to engage and build consensus among all stakeholders 17%
4. Capacity to mobilize information and knowledge 66%
5. Capacity to monitor, evaluate and report and learn at the sector and project levels 33%

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Landscape level Strategic Plan that provides an enabling policy environment for mainstreaming biodiversity conservation into production sectors

target.comment: 1 Strategic Plan

actual.comment: 1. The Biodiversity Friendly Strategic Plan (BFSP) prepared and submitted to MoEF&CC and the same has been forwarded to the Government of Andhra Pradesh for implementation. 2. As there were several landscape level changes in the project area in the last couple of years, the committee suggested revisiting the strategic plan. and 3. A consultant was hired for upgrading the Biodiversity Friendly Landscape and Seascape level Plan in view of latest findings and the work has been initiated.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Amount of resources available for funding the Foundation and the compliance of approved sectoral plans

baseline.comment: NA

actual.comment:
1. MSME: Micro Small and Medium Enterprises-Development Institute, Visakhapatnam which is implemented under ministry of MSME, Government of India has given training to the 35 youth in the EGREE operation area for the livelihood diversification. The institute has given assurance for long term collaorations with EGREE Foundation.
2. SMART: Skills for Manufacturing of Apparel through Research & Training which is the supported organization of Ministry of Textiles, Government of India has offered Rs. 50.0 Lakhs worth of machineries and services to impart textile training for the local communities in large scale which will further help develop alternate livelihood opportunities in the region. Trained members have been linked with DRDA programmes/ apparel industries. Totally 50 members have been trained at 50% institutional fees.
3. The project is negotiating to depute one representative from each line department/sector/ Panchayat in the District/ Local Administration to coordinate and communicate with EGREE Foundation in the project area for effective co-funding and implementation of cross-sectoral plans prepared by the UNDP/GEF Godavari Project.
4. The corporate giants like Reliance are willing to tie up with EGREE Foundation to execute livelihood activities through their CSR/ CER funds. Similarly Corporate Environment Responsibility (CER) allocation from production/corporate sectors, by the end of the project, the Foundation itself will be in compliance to continue the programme through EGREE Foundation . Advocacy programmes conducted till date with all the corporates in the EGREE Region are showing a very positive response and the corporates are showing interest in the objectives of the project.
5. Due to awareness and advocacy programmes conducted till date almost all the line departments/ Enforcement Institutions/ Community institutions in the EGREE Region are showing very positive response and participating and adopting the recommendations/ suggestions provided and are conducting the awareness/community strengthening/enforcement programmes in the objective of the project, which is a good sign for future programmes, as the plan is for EGREE Foundation to become a resource centre for the region.
6. A decision has been taken in the NPSC meeting for designating the EGREE Foundation as ENVIS Centre (http://envis.nic.in/about.html), wherein the Government of India will support for issuing newsletters.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Strategies developed for ensuring that existing sector policies mainstream biodiversity conservation

baseline.comment: Policies requiring amendments identified in Year 1

target.comment: Strategies developed for 100% of identified policies

actual.comment: 1. Main policies that require harmonization have been identified. The Project is keenly examining amending the Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972 for inclusion of coastal and marine biodiversity conservation, which have already been adopted in advanced countries having the similar wildlife laws. 2. For the 1st time in India, with the intervention of UNDP/GEF Godavari Project, a separate chapter on Marine Conservation has been included in the proposed Wild Life Action Plan of India from (2017 to 2031) – 15 years. 3. Amending Andhra Pradesh Marine Fisheries Act to be in line with the aquaculture sector expansion, mesh size regulations etc. as recommended by the Aquaculture and Fisheries sectoral plans of GoI-UNDP-GEF-GoAP project. These were discussed with all stakeholders during the National level Consultation Workshop organized during 25th May, 2015. Inputs were given on the draft Fisheries Action Plan of AP State Government. and 4. Coromandel Fertilizers, Kakinada operating in the EGREE Region is one of the foremost industries to incorporate the biodiversity friendly practices into their operations with the support of EGREE Foundation. Coromandel Fertilizers as part of their compliance has to allot 50% of its land for plantations. However, the site selected for the plantation was a wetland, which is a good habitat for waterbirds especially Darters. In fact, this habitat is recorded as home to the 2nd largest Darter population in India after Gujarat. When Coromandel Fertilizers was about to start conversion of the wetland into plantation, EGREE Foundation intervened and liaised with the State Pollution Control Board and assisted in obtaining permission for protecting the wetlands , by requesting the local Forest Officials to provide wetland plant species, which could be shown as plantations for fulfilment of forest /environmental compliance. With this initiative, the EGREE Foundation could mainstream biodiversity conservation into production sector in around 30 acres. Further, EGREE Foundation was able to conserve the second largest habitat of Darters in India.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: By project end, any new manufacturing units entering the licensing process in the EGREE are subject to the CRZ 2010 Guidelines

target.comment: By project end, any new manufacturing units entering the licensing process in the EGREE are subject to the new guidelines that also incorporate climate change considerations

actual.comment:
Not Applicable. Will be rated in Final Evaluation.
However, the following information is provided as per the discussions held during MTR:. 1. The Project has initiated coordination with one of the World Bank projects, called SICOM mainly for coastal zone management and will initiate integrated coastal zone management plan for EGREE region. 2. The climate change studies and Evaluation of Ecosystem Studies are completed and the final report is being finalized for the EGREE region; therefore this component can be evaluated during the Final Evaluation. 3. The VK-PCPIR corridor is under consideration and the process for it is almost finalized. The negative impacts of the corridor on the ecology of the area which should be counterbalanced through various environmental mitigation measures have already been discussed in the two public hearings conducted till date. In connection with the to be established LNG floating terminal and expansion of Kakinada Sea Port, huge dredging activities are being under taken near Hope Island which protects Kakinada City from natural calamities. Concerns and modifications required were presented and shared with concerned authorities by the GoI-UNDP-GEF-GoAP Project team. and 4. Also, the combined 2nd NPSC meeting has agreed to propose the site as a Ramsar Site and the proposal has been moved in this regard.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Incentives for production sector companies to promote biodiversity friendly practices by giving them opportunities for marketing/ advertising their efforts

target.comment: By Year 2 at least 2-3 companies take up this incentive; By year 5, at least 10 companies take up this incentive

actual.comment: The EGREE Foundation has been established during December, 2013 and the Governing Board has also been established. The protocols and guidelines to achieve the goals of cross sectoral platform mechanism for mainstreaming coastal and marine biodiversity are yet to be approved by the Governing Board in view of the recent recommendations and course corrections proposed in the MTR. The EGREE Foundation is collaborating with Global Reporting Initiative - India for training on sustainable reporting and certification of the eco-friendly industries of the region

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Enhanced capacity of sector institutions for implementing a biodiversity-friendly sector plan including monitoring and enforcement of regulations

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Sector-specific biodiversity-compatible plans

target.comment: Sectoral plans for Fisheries, Aquaculture, Salt pans, Manufacturing units, Ports and Shipping, Tourism

actual.comment: 1. Sector Plans viz., Oil & Natural Gas, Tourism, Fisheries and Aquaculture were prepared and key recommendations were discussed among the stakeholders and policy makers through the national level combined consultation workshop conducted on 25th May, 2015; 2. Key recommendations of the Fisheries and Aquaculture sectors have been incorporated in the AP State Fisheries Action Plan prepared during 2015; and 3. Best practices recommended by the Fisheries, Tourism and Aquaculture sectoral plans are under implementation. At least 5-10 good practices for biodiversity conservation are taken up in collaboration with Andhra Pradesh Tourism Development Corporation, Andhra Pradesh Forest Department, Andhra Pradesh Fisheries Department and local stakeholders.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of representatives from the key sectors (government and private) trained in mainstreaming approaches

target.comment: Production sector: 1,000 Conservation sector: 300 Livelihood sector: 10,000

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Compendium of best practices on mainstreaming biodiversity for key production sector

actual.comment:
1. A short term consultant has been hired to prepare the initial draft plan for making the compendium of best practices, and
2. By the end of 2015, when all the sectoral plans are in place, their findings will be incorporated into the Compendium of Best Practices.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Use of correct fishing gear by commercial fishing operations (indicator, baselines and targets will have to be re-visited once the Sector Plans are prepared by mid-term)

baseline.comment: Limited use (baseline to be measured in 1st 3 months of project)

target.comment: By project end, at least 70-80% of commercial fishing operations are using correct fishing gear

actual.comment:
1. About 150 (37.5%) operational mechanized boats are using correct fishing gear till date due to project interventions, and
2. MTR suggested removing this indicator as it a long term process, and will actually bear effective result only after the project period.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Decline in pesticide concentration in the effluents of aqua farms in the target landscape (indicator, baselines and targets will have to be re-visited once the Sector Plans are prepared by mid-term)

baseline.comment: Baseline concentrations to be measured in 1st 3 months of project

target.comment: 70-80% decline over baseline concentrations

actual.comment: The effluents released from the 10 more aquaculture farms were collected and analyzed at reputed lab at Hyderabad. As all the 33 samples during 2014 were collected during winter month, further to cross check the values 10 more samples were collected and analyzed. No drastic seasonal variations were found. All these results showed that there is a drastic decline in the pesticide concentrations in aqua farms as the State Government of Andhra Pradesh has introduced a disease resistant exotic species, Litopenaeus vannamei. Moreover the pesticides like Endosulphan and Nuvan have been banned by the Government from use.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Effluents from manufacturing units (indicator, baselines and targets will have to be re-visited once the Sector Plans are prepared by mid-term)

baseline.comment: Baseline to be defined in consultation with the Pollution Control Board at time of approval of Sector Plans

target.comment: Decline of 70-80% over baseline

actual.comment: Negotiated with the Godavari Knowledge Park who are working on the coastal and marine biotechnology. Farmer friendly solutions are initiated through improved technology to overcome the above problem. Exposure trips for the farmers are being planned to the best practice areas in Gujarat. Stakeholders consultation meetings are proposed to discuss a comprehensive study to be undertaken in collaboration with APPCB to understand cumulative impact of pollution load in the natural ecosystem of the EGREE region. Further, sectoral plans will be approved in the Governing Body meeting.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Management Effectiveness Evaluation (MEE) Scorecard

baseline.comment: Baseline to be measured in 1st 3 months of project

target.comment: MEE score improves by 20% by year 3 of the project and 30 % by year 5

actual.comment: The new Management Plan for the period 2013-2023 is in place with monitoring protocol. An independent MEE team would assess the management effectiveness of Coringa Wildlife Sanctuary and contribute to the MoEFCC monitoring report. The MTR gave highly satisfactory rating for this indicator.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Community livelihoods and natural resource use are sustainable in the EGREE

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of SHGs/ CBOs strengthened

target.comment: In 44 abutting villages 709 SHGs; 20 EDCs; 16 Fishermen Association; 33 Women Organization; 5 NGOs; 17 Youth Clubs; and 5 Dairy Cooperatives are strengthened

actual.comment: 1. NRM/ environmental awareness programmes were carried out for nature clubs formed with the help of schools, colleges and universities in the EGREE region through the GoI-UNDP-GEF-GoAP Godavari Project; 2. 3 more Village Youth clubs were formed to promote NRM programmes through EGREE Foundation;

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of skills- development activities carried out for SHGs/ CBOs/ and other local institutions for alternative and/ or sustainable ecosystem-based livelihoods that reduce pressures on biodiversity

target.comment: Target to be defined after design of the micro-plans

actual.comment:
3. The project has carried out a total of 518 programmes reaching out to 11736 people, as detailed below:
a. Skill Enhancement Programme (Skill Trainings and Exposure Visits): Conducted Skill Training and Exposure visits (19 programmes involving 402 people) on fish post harvesting technology, industrial motivational campaigns, Micro Small and Medium Entrepreneurship (MSME) and development programmes, training on Apparel Designing and Fashion Technology etc. for women groups, youth and SHGs, computer training for youth, training for cooperatives in commodities marketing, for earning better incomes and thus enabling them to improve their quality of life . Exposure trips to Fishery Research Institutes / Cooperatives/ Dairy development Institutes/ Alternative Livelihood options to the youth, women and other dependents of the natural resources of EGREE.
b. Institutional Strengthening (Capacity Building): Conducted 24 Capacity building programmes for 497 members of EDC/ VSS/ CBOs/ NGOs/ Cooperatives/ SHGs, Line Departments, youth groups, and Panchayats. Strengthened EDCs-20, VSS-9, Women Groups-20, Cooperatives-3, Youth Clubs-5, NGOs-4.
c. Awareness building programmes; Conducted 196 Awareness building programmes for 4630 members on sustainable fisheries management systems, grazing regime and fuel wood extraction defined under the developed microplans
d. Village level meetings/ Consultations and Tie-ups: Conducted Village level Consultations (280) with resource users (6207 people) for discussing rights and responsibilities, village development motivation, capacity building and distribution of supporting implements, modifications to catch size, fishing tools (nets, etc), better management of fishing activity to minimize associated waste generated etc.
e. Networking (Building Social Capital): Initiated Networking (6 networks) (Sarpanch Samikya Sangham) Forest Protection Groups (Federation of Eco-development committees and Vansmarakshana Samities) and Fishermen groups (District Fishermen Association) and village leaders for a) Better governance and for initiating pro conservation activities b) Strengthening the networks c) Activating the village assemblies/Gramasabhas for discussing and addressing the village development and biodiversity conservation activities (Micro plans).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of people shifting to alternative livelihood options that reduce pressure on biodiversity

baseline.comment: Baseline to be collected in Year 1

target.comment: Target to be defined after design of the micro-plans

actual.comment:
Based on the recommendations of the microplans, the project is implementing livelihood and awareness generation activities in 37 villages in the project area. Among them 10 high dependent villages have been highly prioritized and resource development/ alternative livelihood activities have been initiated in these villages through the Andhra Pradesh Forest and Fisheries Depts.
I. Fishery development of post harvest technology to the fisher men and women and supporting technically improved equipment. In addition, 1. Strengthening the village infrastructure: a. Community halls which were in bad shape were renovated as community extension and information centers and are now being used for conducting meetings/ awareness programmes/ educating the youth club women groups on biodiversity conservation etc. b. Constructed fish drying yard and dairy milk collection center to support the resource users for enhancing their livelihood opportunities.c. Supported construction of a hygienic market and landing space at Matlapalem with the collaboration of Fisheries department, Kakinada, d. Fish processing centre at Chollangi Snanala Revu, Highway fish stall at Kobbarichettu Peta villages. e. Conducted pilot fish stall with the trained women at Kakinada town to tie up with local and district retail market network for sales and marketing of the processed fish. f. Distributed Eco-friendly Fishing gear to 7 fishermen groups (70 fishermen) at Matlapalem village.
II. Promoting alternative livelihoods and collaboration with institutions. 2. Provided Micro-credit support for establishing Micro Entrepreneurship programme to Matlapalem, Uppalanka and Clollangi Snanala Revu villages based on this, initiated linking this programme with A.P State Government Programme ‘Capital Infusion Fund’ through District Rural Development Agency (DRDA), EG Dt.
3. Created linkages between the trained candidates of Nature Guides and Cookery courses with Andhra Pradesh Tourism Development Corporation (APTDC).
4. EF established Alternative Livelihood training center (SMART Skill Camp) in collaboration with ATDC, Hyd (Ministry of Jute and Textile) and imparted training to 50 community women. The women initiated DISHA society for textile designing and manufacturing unit. Initiated tie-up with DRDA, industrial textile manufacturing units, industries for bulk orders to the trained women.
III. Promoting Community based Eco-Tourism.
5. Strengthening of Community Based Eco Tourism (CBET): Supported the Forest Department to construct and procure necessary infrastructure for strengthening of CBET at Chollangi and Ramannapalem (Jetty, Gate, Arch, Dust bins, Murals, Eco autos, Publicity material etc.,
6. Also, the Forest Department has allocated land for constructing a Centre for Community Knowledge on Coastal Conservation (CCKCC) under the umbrella of the EGREE Foundation

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Incidents of felling of mangrove trees, non-adherence to the seasonal ban on fishing, destructive fishing practices by local communities within the project area in contravention of community natural resource use plan

baseline.comment: Baseline to be measured in 1st 3 months of project

target.comment: Declines by 50% by year 5, compared with baseline levels

actual.comment:
1. Due to ongoing awareness and enforcement programmes there has been a further 10% decline (thus making it a total of 20% decline) in the mangrove felling during the reporting period.
2. Fishing ban period of one and half months from 15th April 2014 to 31st May is maintained by the local fishing communities.
2. About 150 (37.5%) operational mechanized boats are using correct fishing gear till date due to project interventions, and
3. MTR suggested removing this indicator as it a long term process, and will actually bear effective result only after the project period.

result.title: 57755 hectares
result.description: To ensure a mosaic of land uses and community practices across the rural landscape to generate sustainable livelihoods and global benefits for BD, LD and CCM

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of hectares of land brought under sustainable land and resource management in the Western Ghats (WG), Himalayan Front (HF) and Arid and Semi-Arid Regions (ASAR)

baseline.comment: 0 ha.

target.comment: 200,000 hectares

actual.comment:
Against a grant allocation of US $1.100 million for biodiversity conservation, a budget commitment of US $1.070 has been done through 35 projects.
Presently Biodiversity conservation, and use is happening in 78,948 hectares in WG, HF, ASAR in eastern and central India.
Nearly 871 villages (80,000 households) are impacted directly and the technology and process spread is happening naturally in neighbouring kinship areas. Several projects are in protected and community conserved areas working with tribal people.
Regular guidance is provided through a series of Guidance Workshops and by organizing regular Market Places (Green Haats) to link the biodiversity products to markets.
Western Ghats: In WGs nearly 323 villages impacted. Vechur Trust collaborated with University of Veterinary and Animal Sciences in making improved local breed semen available for breeding of Vechur cows which is supplied to 4 centres. Nearly 1100 households have been approached through various trainings in the conservation of the breed. MNTN has now been active in promoting the integration into other 10 Panchayats of the Malabari Goat Conservation project. Nearly 200 women Groups linked to NABARD and local breed conservation to Malabari. SEVA has been promoting the conservation of Vembur sheep in 10 Panchayats. Innovation of community led mangrove conservation in 100 ha with 4 different varieties.
More than 18 new products established by KFI based on the local biodiversity, e.g. Brown Rice, Honey, turmeric powder, red chillies, etc. PLANT has built 200 artificial structures for Reef Management, increasing marine biodiversity and fish breeding for alternate livelihood measures. Shashwat has increased and focussed on fish biodiversity with 4 ornamental fish.
In Arid and Semi Arid Regions: In ASAR nearly 358 villages are impacted. In many projects like SSE (20 core and 10 dissemination villages); Sarjana (30/15), Sujagriti (7/20), SYSS (7/10); SRIDA (10/10); GVSS (5/10), Samarthak Samiti (9/25) more than 30,000 ha area is directly impacted through women SHGs in conservation of local protected areas; new plantations of Bamboo, Guggal, Neem, Satavar and Plash/Tamrind grown.
Himalayan Front: In HF nearly 190 villages are impacted. In Bioved, 50 beneficiaries from 11 NGO partners had training in lac production, decorative, dyes, scientific methods of lac cultivation. They trained on 1000 lac host plants in 40 ha and later 11 NGOs taking up in 5000 ha. In Bihar Development Trust (BDT), 20 farmers growing 3 varieties in 20 ha land, listing 25 women SHGs (250 women) engaged in developing 22 artisans and linking markets for 27 new products. In Lotus, in 45 villages, 120 farmers are conserving 18 different varieties over an area of 350 ha in 18 villages. Linking some varieties to markets.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: # tons of carbon emission reductions achieved through SGP interventions

baseline.comment: 200,000 metric tonnes per year of CO2e

target.comment: 75,000 metric tonnes of CO2e per year reduced

actual.comment:
Nearly 79,450 MTs of CO2e have been reduced through 27 projects by adopting measures like fuel-efficient cook-stoves, biogas units, protection and plantation of mangroves, carbon sequestration, SRI techniques, enrichment plantations, biomass briquettes, large fuel-efficient cook-stoves, solar technologies and water harvesting are simultaneously improving the livelihoods of the poor and marginalized communities.
In projects like Manuvikasa (50 large size cook-stoves) Peermade (50 large cook-stoves), GSMT (500 cook-stoves), Vikas Samarthan (50 biogas), CORE (Fly-ash Bricks, 390 toilets), SYSS (250 cook-stoves), PK Thampan (60 biogas), Kurseong Disha, PPSS for plantations over 300 hac is helping to reduce CO2 emissions.
In most of the projects, the actions are encouraged through women SHGs and locals are encouraged to take decisions, and communities contribute 25-40% costs in technology up-take. In each of the project, nearly 2-3 persons are trained in the up-keep of the technology repair/maintenance. Links of locals provided to Service Providers. Projects like Sarthak, plastic recycling (700 MTs/p.a.) and Hunnarshala (100 MTs solid waste management) are contributing to CO2 emission reduction.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Amount of new and additional financial resources leveraged for community driven sustainable resource management in India.
Improvement in Systemic Level Indicators of Capacity Development Scorecard (Annex 3)

target.comment: USD 5 million

actual.comment:
Against the total OP5 grant commitment of US $2,445,381 so far, a co-financing of US $4,798,986 (196%) has been linked up by the NGOs/CBOs as in-kind and in-cash contributions through government schemes, Forest, Livestock, Agriculture and Watershed Departments, banks and rural credits.
Also nearly 250,000 USD have been sourced from MoEF&CC, UNDP and private sector sources. By the end of the project, we will be able to fully achieve the target

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Improvement in Systemic Level Indicators of Capacity Development Scorecard (Annex 3)

baseline.comment:
SYSTEMIC LEVEL (The baselines and targets against the following capacities to be assessed at the time of selecting individual grantees). B/L Tgt.
1. Capacity to conceptualize and formulate local level policies, actions on sustainable resource use.
2. Capacity to implement programmes and action on sustainable resource use
3. Capacity to engage and build consensus among all stakeholders
4. Capacity to mobilize information and knowledge
5. Capacity to monitor, evaluate and report and learn at the grantee and project levels

target.comment:
22 guidance workshops by the end of project
1. 900 NGOs and CBOs by the end of the project
2. 900 NGOs/CBOs by the end of the project
3. 10 Institutions and 500 NGOs/CBOs by the end of project
4.10 institutions linked and 12 different technologies adopted by the end of project by the grantees
5. 90 NGO/CBO partners at the end of project have community capacities created in practicing two/three technologies.

actual.comment:
1. 26 Guidance Workshops organized in OP5. 10 workshops organized during one year, at different Regions of the country. 8 Regional Committee meetings organized; total 16 RCMs done and total of 1204 proposals reviewed and only 77 approved, also nearly 29 are in pipeline for better development; the capacities of NGOs/CBOs enhanced by arranging exposure visits to successful projects, adopting tested technologies and linking them with government programs, Departmental trainings (as co-financing), and financial institutions to enhance the scope of project activities.
2. Nearly 792 NGO members participated in these workshops on a range of issues. The follow-up Guidance Workshops organized after each NSC helping NGOs to understand Results Based Monitoring, reporting, and how to develop uniform pattern of documentation and impact-oriented advocacy material, usage of Logos, etc.
3. 145 NGOs linked to more than 14 national and State level institutions technology/service providers. The institutions linked are
1. Lac Research Station, Ranchi
2. JNKVV agricultural University, Jabalpur and Similarly other Agricultural Universities in States
3. Krishi Vigyan Kendras (KVKs) in the respective project districts.
4. Organic Farming Board under GOI, Ghaziabad
5. Fisheries, Livestock, Forest and Agricultural Departments and Renewable Energy depts. in the respective states of the projects,
6. MGIRI, Wardha
7.Seeds Division, NBPG&R, ICAR,New Delhi and its partner institutions like, CIAE, Bhopal and IGFRI, Jhansi.
8. Indian Institute of Science (IISc), Bangalore
9. National Medicinal Plant Board, New Delhi
10. State Biodiversity Boards, and State Medicinal Plant Boards in respective states
11. National Biodiversity Authority (NBA), Chennai
12. Fodder Research Stations, Ministry of Agriculture, GOI
13. Department of Science and Technology.
Some examples are: Lotus Society made to visit Lok Panchayat and learn about setting up Seed/Grain Banks. est practices adopted by Vruksh Prem on development of seed banks, Conare on development of good quality fodder and Yerala Society to link up their products for marketing were shared and learning visits encouraged. The 34 NGOs taken to Central Institute of Agricultural Engineering, Bhopal and exposed to land conservation methods and modern agricultural equipments for adopting in projects.
4. More than 65 NGOs linked to 9 different technologies, e.g. cook-stoves, oil-expellers, milletullers, bamboo biogas units, floating biogas units, sickles, harrows, chaff-cutters, solar cookers, heaters, etc. A special technology interface workshop on successful use and application of Biogas Units organized on 1st Nov 2014 and 25 NGO from different parts of the country participated and learnt about new and economical models of biogas units. The pioneers in use of Biogas technologies, including private sector invited to share details adopting different ways of managing the slurry, Biogas and cow dung and explaining cost benefit of each mode Links to pre-harvest and post-harvest technologies and value addition done. Guidance and exposure provided to NGO partners, like PLANT, Mahatma Phule and CENSFOOD to access more CSR funds. SRIDA, Sujagriti, Sarjana created BMCs and working with Jabalpur Agricultural University and State Biodiversity Boards, Madhya Pradesh and Chhatisgarh States.
5. Almost all 77 partners taking up 3/4 technologies with communities in an integrated manner. The projects are taken up by developing institutions like Self Help Groups, Farmers Groups, Village Volunteering Groups, etc involved in planning by linking up the local resources and the common community property.
NGOs/CBOs through adoption of new technologies, have access to funds and mainstreamed with Government programs for availing better social and economic opportunities for creating policy influence in projects like PPSS, MNTN, CCD, Samekit, PLANT, IIPM, GSMT and KFI. Nearly 45 Exchange and Learning Visits organized.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Outcome 1.1: Panchayats (local self governments) incorporate improved management practices into village level planning for community managed landscapes and seascapes enhancing mosaics of landuses and improving biodiversity conservation.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of panchayats incorporating sustainable management practices into village level resource use plans.

target.comment: 30 by year 4

actual.comment: 43 Panchayats incorporated sustainable management practices into village level resource use planning by making the communities a part of the decision-making by allotting revenue land for setting up check dams, water harvesting systems, developing grazing lands, and fodder plots, mangroves restoration, cook-stoves, honey collection etc. GSMT, MPSS, GVNML, Kheti Virasat, Shashwat, CCD, We Care Society, Samekit, CORE and Sujagriti have used funds from Government/ Agriculture and MNREGA funds through Panchayats.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of community led tools and methodologies developed for biodiversity mapping, monitoring and valuation.

actual.comment: In 16 projects (Sujagriti, Sarjana, GSMT, THA, SRIDA, KFI, Gram Sudhar Samiti, CONARE, PPSS, BRASS etc. ), the grantees are promoting Biodiversity Registers, Participatory Rural Appraisals in building and mapping the priority use of local biodiversity, setting up biodiversity gardens for conservation of seeds and fruits, setting up herbariums, better extraction and value addition for market links, enterprise development for improved livelihoods.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of rare and threatened domesticated cultivars/ livestock/ varieties brought under focused conservation practices in the project sites.

target.comment: At least 5

actual.comment:
07 rare and threatened agro, animal and plant varieties conserved, i.e. “Guggul; and in THA project (08) Medicinal Plant”, Mangroves varieties like Avicenna alba, Avicenna Marina.
3 salt resistant Rice Varieties, like, Malaboti, Dudheswar, Swanamasuri, and Jhingashal; Vechur Cow, Vembur Sheep, and protection of Sacred Groves.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of women's groups formed/ strengthened for planning and executing of sustainable natural resource management

baseline.comment: 50 (This is based on the past experience of the SGP and shall be firmed up after individual grantees are identified.)

target.comment: 100 (This is based on the past experience of the SGP and shall be firmed up after individual grantees are identified.)

actual.comment:
A total of 679 Women Self Help Groups have been formed/ strengthened comprising 13,795 women members who do regular savings, have opened bank accounts and accessed credit to generate substantial co-financing. Nearly 391, 803 USD savings have happened in projects and they have sourced nearly 590,000 USD as loans and grants in projects
To ensure sustainability in most of SGP projects, the main focus has been on establishing/ strengthening the institutional structure and empowering the communities in managing the projects themselves.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of new branding/ geographic indicators/ certified agro-based products developed in the project sites.

target.comment: 5 by project end.

actual.comment: Nearly 07 Brands created through different partners, i.e. (1) Vechur Cow ghee and urine and other medicinal products created. (2) KFI has promoted NTFPs into marketable products and branded them; (3) Brown Rice, organic wheat based products by Sarjana and Sujagriti; and also (4) three types of Millets by Arambha and Nirman. (5) Desert Honey by Samrthak; (6) Oils and medicated hair Oils by SEE. (7) Bamboo products by BDT. More partners like Sujagrati, Lotus, TIDE, Samekit, SESA, SYSS and are also getting into registering products.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Outcome 2.1: Appropriate energy efficient technologies result in emission reductions.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of tonnes of CO2e emission reductions achieved through adoption of energy efficient technologies.

baseline.comment: 150,000 metric tonnes per year.

target.comment: 225,000 tonnes of CO2e emission reductions over 3 years.

actual.comment:
Against a budget of US $2.224 million for climate change portfolio, a commitment of US $1.110 million has been done through 27 projects out of a total of 77 approved so far.
A range of simple and low-cost EE technologies relating to briquetting units, waste recycling, biomass driers, improved cook-stoves and biogas have been adopted.
More than 79,450 MTs of CO2 emission checked through a range of alternate energy and EE technologies adopted by Vivekananda Trust, Sarjana, SESS, CORE, Muskan Jyoti, IIPM, TIDE, Shashwat and other partners.
Nearly 1600 improved and fuel-efficient cook-stoves constructed (900 alone by Vivekananda Trust, 200 by Mahatma Phule, 150 by Shashwat, 200 by SYSS, 45 by Earthwatch, 35 by SSE and 30 by Manuvikasa and rest by others).
82 Biogas units set up in more than 20 projects (31 by Peekay Tree, 22 by Friends of Doon Society, 20 by VSK and 09 by Chhatrasal). Two different models (floating dome and Ferro-cement) have been tried.
Sujagriti, SSYS and Sarjana were trained in the appropriate cook-stove technologies at the CEE/SAIL project site in Gonda. GSMT visited Arti to adopt cook-stove designs. Nagarika Trust and We Care Society adopted the cook-stove technologies from TIDE.
SYSS and Shashwat made visits to MGIRI to learn about new solar based technologies and adopting into the SGP projects. The trainings are happening for communities and NGOs with service providers.
ZIRCORD has taken up with 04 Panchayats the setting up of biomass briquettes based on rice-husk. Also CCD and Sarjana are adopting low cost technologies of bio-briquetting.
A special meeting was organized with BAREFOOT POWER for accessing and sharing their technologies. Partners like SYSS, Kurseong Disha, GVNML, and VSK are adopting the RE technologies in their projects.
SSE is exploring the opportunities for putting up micro-hydro unit under the project. More impacts of CO2 emission reduction will emerge close to completion of the project activities.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: # of women involved through SHGs in investments for emissions reductions

baseline.comment: to be assessed in the initial phase of the project.

target.comment: 10% increase by end of year 2 and 20% increase by end of year 4

actual.comment:
Through projects like TIDE, NERD, Sujagrati, GVSS and Disha, efforts are being made to encourage the partners to access the emission reduction technologies through investments from their savings.
Presently, about 5% of SHGs are making investments in adoption of such technologies through their savings. Women entrepreneurs have sourced small technologies, e.g. solar lanterns, solar torches and mobile phone chargers with small pen-light cells.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: # of tonnes CO2e emissions reduced through adoption of renewable energy technologies at local level.

baseline.comment: 50,000 metric tonnes per year

target.comment: 12,277 tonnes of CO2e. by end of project.

actual.comment:
7,000 tons of CO2 emissions are being reduced through renewable energy technologies like solar energy, solar lanterns, solar driers for multiple applications (including fish drying), power generating water mills (16) and Micro Hydels (01). In learning from SGP SAIL project has done 250 solar lanterns in a business case and two street lights installed.
In NERD, two women led SHGs formed for laying out two biogas units to produce electricity.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Outcome 3.1 Improved enabling environment at the panchayat level agricultural sector improves management, functionality and cover of agro-ecosystems in ASAR (LD-1).

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: No of hectares of dry agricultural lands brought under SLM with improved vegetative cover.

target.comment: 70,000 hectares

actual.comment:
Nearly 42,000 hectares of land brought under sustainable management through 15 projects. Against an allocation of US $366,833, a commitment of US $264,636 has been done.
Majority of the projects are with the poorest of the poor and with PVTGs (Particularly Vulnerable Tribal Groups) in the remote areas and are in line with the national priorities, e.g. Spandan, Paramparagat, CHARDEP, GSS, WEEDS, Nishwarth and Dharti are all by the protected areas.
Under GVSS project, 3 large size canal bunds and under Vruksh Prem 2 check-dams were constructed and waste land brought under additional cultivation resulting in increased income of farmers by 3-4 times. 35 hectares of degraded/waste land brought under additional cultivation in Dausa and Bandi-Kui Districts, situated on the foot-hills of Aravali mountain range in Rajasthan State. 9 hectares of fodder land brought under additional grazing in GVNML project in Rajasthan through locally devised Chauka systems of rainwater harvesting. More than 57 fodder plots developed by CONARE in Andhra Pradesh State linking with Forage Department, Hyderabad, Ministry of Agriculture. More than 27,000 mangrove plantations made in 25 hectares of land area by PPSS, Machlipatnam (Andhra Pradesh).
Six project partners (Conare, SYSS, GVNML, Mahila Haat, MNTN and Chhatrasal) developed fodder plots to link up with the project activities. More than 400 ha land development actions undertaken by Manuvikasa. 560 ha of rice cultivation done by Sarjana, 600 ha millets by Paryavaraniya Vikas, 450 ha by SRIDA through demonstrations on minor millets, and Jowar. Sujagriti has brought 1700 ha area under cultivation through earthen bunds with spillways also called -dor bandi-
61 Feeding Troughs set up to divert cattle from free grazing to stall fed conditions and to reduce burden on forests. Agreements done with beneficiaries that 2 of their animals will not be sent to forest for grazing.
Peekay Tree Crops promoted 4 women’s food processing units – two tailoring units and two commercial scale protected agriculture farms, 12 goat breeding/ rearing units, one community marketing outlet, one horticulture nursery and 15 quail farming units. 20 family farms are supported with vegetable planting materials and 500 tree saplings.
SESA, PUPA, PPSS, MPSSS visited Fodder Institutes for accessing improved quality seeds. 123 compost pits developed and linked to the slurry emanating from the biogas units set up under the project (20 at GVSS, 3 at Friends of Doon Society, 30 in SMS; 50 in We Care Society). SYSS and Mahila Haat have also developed simple pits for composting. Planning started for increasing soil productivity on 1600 Ha in Muskan Jyoti.
Three community institutions registered for managing the Eco-Pulpers by IIPM and nearly 150% water reduction has happened per day (400 litres per 1000 kgs of coffee pulping to earlier 7000 litres). In the 3 centres during the last one year (for 65 days of operation), the reduction has been 35,67,000 litres of water. With the successful impacts emerging, the NGO is taking up a Full Scale GEF project.
Nearly 23 wells constructed under the Jaldhara Schemes of the States. In Gravis, 4 tanks have been made of 300 cubic feet which are holding nearly 8000 litres (1 cu. ft is = 23.1 litres of water). The life span of these units being 20 years, the cost of water storage is 0.003 paisa per litre.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of new and additional sources identified for leveraging investment replication/ for SLM across drylands in ASAR.

target.comment: At least 10 new sources

actual.comment:
As explained earlier, projects have leveraged resources for land development and linked to MNREGA – a Government of India initiative in dry land, remote districts; and Watershed funds. More than 45 wells recharged in the area resulting into increased irrigation (NGOs like MPSS, Shashwat, SRIDA, GVSS, GSMT, SAMEKIT and Gram Sathi).
Many Panchayats are linking MNREGA program within the villages in projects. Panchayats are providing approvals for areas for plantations, road construction (Mahatma Phule, SRIDA, Kurseong Disha, Nirman, Samarthak and APOWA), Mangroves (PPSS), formation of Biodiversity Management Committees (Sujagriti, Sarjana, KFI and SYSS). All these actions will set a platform for replication activities in the projects.
More partners like Dharti, SYSS, Niswarth and Samekit are also developing similar links in the coming year.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: % density of ground stocking in productive forest landscape in ASAR, HF,WG.

target.comment: Ground stocking increased to 50%

actual.comment:
These are estimates made from the Mid Term reviews in projects and talks with locals. The ground stock increase is taking place in 3 ways: (and Direct and Indirectly in all 3 ways)
(1) Plantations: In 85% projects, plantations are taking place due to multiple sources of financing/initiatives of SHGs/Forest Department and MNREGA. In last 3 years, more than 100,000 plantations of trees with multiple species in projects.
(2) SWC Measures: Due to introduction of soil and water conservation measures in projects, the local biodiversity strengthening is already taking place. As many of the works are in and around protected forest areas, there is natural growth of the stock in place.
(3) Wood USE Savings: Thirdly, in several projects on improved cook-stoves, bio gas units have taken up in the periphery of protected areas/reserved forests and this is leading to reduce pressures on forests – the exact amount of saving can be gauged through each project.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Outcome 4.1 Increased capacity of SGP stakeholders to diagnose and understand the complex and dynamic nature of global environmental problems and to develop local solutions.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of new grants that replicate consolidated approaches (BD, CC, LD).

target.comment: Replication of consolidated approaches (BD, CC, LD) in at least 30 new grants by year 4.

actual.comment:
17 replication and scaling up projects have been taken up under all the 3 GEF thematic areas and operational zed. This has been undertaken with the twin objectives of broadening the areas, and technologies uptake from the project and partner institutions.
The projects have shown greater promise, access to government Schemes; GEF benefits; co financing and sustainable institution creation, brand building, business models. The focus in GEF SGP is to create a niche through scaling up and make communities responsible and have greater ownerships, skills and practices. Many of the projects have already developed sustainable institutions as Producer Co. and Cooperatives etc for long term sustainable development.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Increase in amount of co-funding for SGP-India.

target.comment: USD 5 million

actual.comment: US $4.82 million by NGOs/ CBOs. US $50,000 in-kind technical contribution and $10,000 in cash by UNDP. US $400,000 by private sector. The progress so far is satisfactory and with the links established already with Wells for India; AIRBUS Corporate Foundation; JSW; NMPB; and others. The target will be increased at the end of the project. More contributions from the scaling up initiatives in projects will be much more and still 20 projects will be approved.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number natural resource based products developed by the GEF SGP partners linked to markets.

baseline.comment: 25 numbers at present

target.comment: 75 products by project end

actual.comment: 74 natural resource based products developed and linked to market through more than 35 projects. Details of these projects are up-loaded regularly on SGP website (www.sgpindia.org). Regular facilitation is done to establish market linkages for these products through 3 Green Haat (Market Place) events that have been put up in association with the Ministry of Environment, Forest & Climate Change, and UNDP. A consultant has been appointed to explore the possibilities of e-marketing by assisting the NGOs to have test certifications and quality focus.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of workshops/learning events conducted by the project by the GEF SGP partners/stakeholders

baseline.comment: GEF SGP partners/stakeholders

target.comment:
Workshops held in the beginning of year 1 to finalise the indicators and targets in the M&E framework with all the stakeholders.
Four learning events organised for key stakeholders/SGP grantees for achieving this outcome.

actual.comment:
With 10 Guidance-cum-Capacity Building workshops organized during the last year, a total of 26 workshops have been organized from the start of the OP5 project.
The NGOs were guided on the linkages to be established with government programs and financial institutions and how the GEFable impacts are to be viewed in the proposals and how the co-financing is to be accessed and the calculations done for reporting purposes.
During the workshops, the learning's from other projects are shared, resource persons (Sector Experts) guide them on new available technologies and how to access them. More than 15 grantees have been linked up with various RE technologies. Details given in the CB section.
Exchange visits - as learning exercises- are arranged that help the NGOs to learn from each other on how to make a Producer Company, improved cultivation practices of horticulture and poly-house culture for better yields and income. A visit of Lotus Society visited was arranged to Lok Panchayat to learn about setting up of Seed/Gran Banks. Samarthak Samiti visited Yerala Society to link up their products for marketing.
Experience of GVSS on exposure visit of their farmers to Agricultural Research Institute was shared with other NGOs and how the farmers benefitted by way of increased cultivation.
GVNML was encouraged to promote for the improved income the local plant variety “Kair” for developing value added products, like pickles which are in high demand in the neighbouring cities of Rajasthan.
The NGOs are briefed on how to write reports to link up with Results Based Monitoring System, how to do calculation of CO2 emission reduction from their operations, and how to develop quality documentation, including film making.
A visit was organized for 51 project partners to Central Institute of Agricultural Engineering, Bhopal to learn about pre and post harvest technologies, easy to operate agricultural tools and implements for reducing the time in various agricultural practices, linking up with renewable energy technologies.
Regular guidance is provided to the Regional Coordinators and CEE teams on how to do the hand-holding and guidance to the NGOs/CBOs on analyzing GEF impacts, institution building in projects and how to assess the measurable impacts.
Support provided to Sarjana who has developed indigenous rice varieties to label them with quality ingredients and link them with markets. More than 250 kgs of Rice sold through network benefitting 23 farmers.

iati-activity.title: Solar concentrator for process heat industries
iati-activity.description: Developing market and promoting solar concentrator based process heat applications in India.

iati-activity.title: Promote solar concentrators
iati-activity.description: Developing market and promoting solar concentrator based process heat applications in India.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Total Area for Solar concentrator collector area installed (m2). 2) Number of solar concentrator technology packages demonstrated 3) Number of persons trained on technical skills on solar concentrators for heat applications. 4) Number of Evaluations conducted 5) Number of newsletters and magazines published

target.comment: 1. Ensure Collector area of 9000 square meters be sanctioned 2. Demonstrate five technology packages 3. Conduct 12 training programmes and train 300 technical personnel such as ITI students on Concentrating Solar Heat applications. 4. Conduct Mid term review of the project 5. Publish monthly e-newsletters, 4 issues of SuNFocus quarterly magazines and activate website.

actual.comment: 1. Collector area of 10084 square meter sanctioned. 2. Five Technology packages [namely, Scheffler, Parabolic trough, Concentrating Parabolic concentrator, dual axis tracked parabolic dish collector, and dual axis tracked Fresnel reflector] demonstrated 3. Conducted 12 training programmes and trained 300 technical personnel such as ITI students on Concentrating Solar Heat applications 4. Completed mid term review of the project 5. Published 12 e-newsletters, 4 issues of SunFocus magazine and website www.cshindia.in is active.

target.comment: 1. Sanction collector area of 10000 square meters 2. Initiative online performance of 14 existing sites 3. Prepare performance based incentive norms for Concentrating Solar heat applications 4. Establish and operationalize state of art test centres [first in Asia] of performance evaluation of Concentrating Solar Heat systems at National Institute of Solar Energy, Gurgaon and University of Pune, Pune 5. Establish testing and demonstration centre at Brahmakumaris at Mount Abu.

result.title: goal
result.description: Reduced GHG emissions from use of CSH systems for low and medium temperature process heat

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Cumulative CO2 emission reduced from start of project to End-Of-Project (EOP), (tCO2e)

actual.comment:
Cumulative CO2 emission reduced from start of the project till 30 June 2015 was 2431 tCO2. During the reporting period 365 tCO2 emissions reduced.
14 CSH demonstration projects (6700 sqm) were sanctioned during the year. 3 of them (1415 sqm) installed. They are, Siddharath Surgical, Valsad (263 m2) commissioned in July 2014. It is estimated to reduce 92 tCO2 annually. Neel Metals, Manesar (612 m2) was commissioned in November 2014, estimated to reduce 143 tCO2 annually. Unique Biotech, Hyderabad (540 m2) was commissioned in March 2015, estimated to reduce 63 tCO2 annually.
One Replication project (338 m2) and 11 smaller projects [1162 m2] were supported under the project. 3 projects (291 m2) were commissioned: CMC Vellore 104 m2, in July 14, reduce 36tCO2 annually. MSA Vadodara 55 m2, in Oct 14, reduce 16 tCO2 annually and PSG Hospital, Coimbatore, in Oct 14, reduce 15 tCO2 annually.

result.title: objective
result.description: Increased use and promotion of CSH systems for low and medium temperature process heat applications

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Cumulative installed area of CSH systems for process heat applications (m2) by EOP
No. of companies that have installed CSH systems by EOP

actual.comment:
Cumulative installed area of CSH systems for process heat applications was 42,307 m2 till 30 June 2015.
No. of companies/establishments that have installed CSH systems by 30 June 2015 was 147.

result.title: Outcome 1.1
result.description: Enhanced understanding of CSH technologies, applications and markets

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
No. of technology package suppliers that are available to market CSH technologies in India by EOP
No. of companies that used the information packages in purchasing and installing CSH process heat systems by EOP

actual.comment:
During the reporting period 2 manufacturers were added thus taking the total to 21 as on 30 June 2015.
Number of companies that agreed for CSH packages is 26 during the reporting period.

result.title: Outcome 1.2
result.description: Adoption of standards and specifications for guidance of manufacturers and users for assurance of CSH quality, safety, and performance

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
No. of Indian CSH system components & equipment manufacturers that comply with the BIS standards and specifications by EOP
No. of Indian CSH system component & equipment manufacturers that entered into the internal CSH business (export of CSH components & equipment) by EOP

actual.comment:
There are 21 CSH manufacturers who follow technical specifications laid down by MNRE. No BIS standards are available for CSH system components.
3 Indian CSH manufactures namely, Thermax, Megawatt Solutions & Forbes Solar are doing business abroad.

result.title: Outcome 1.3
result.description: Adequately capable and operational testing laboratories for verification of manufacturer claims and guidance of CSH users to enable informed decisions

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
No. of accredited testing facilities for CSH components and equipment in India
No. of Indian CSH system component & equipment manufacturers that approached testing laboratories for
No. of international CSH system component & equipment manufacturers that approached Indian testing laboratories for certification to enable their systems sale in Indian market by EOP

actual.comment:
2 Nos of test set ups have been established at National Institute of Solar Energy [NISE], Gurgaon & University of Pune [UoP], Pune.
A total of 9 CSH systems have been tested so far supplied from 4 manufacturers at test center of University of Pune. Two technologies namely Parabolic Trough Collector [PTC] and Scheffler were tested through mobile set up. Two technologies PTC and Compact Linear Fresnel Reflector [CFLR] were tested through Immobile test set ups.
The activity could be taken up after full functioning of test set ups and establishing their reliability.

result.title: Outcome 2.1
result.description: Strengthened technical capacity and awareness of stakeholders of CSH systems for industrial/ institutional process heat applications

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
No. of CSH replication projects by EOP
No. of trained participants of test facilities that are actively involved in the development of the CSH technology development by EOP
No. of CSH technologies available in India by EOP due to increased awareness and capacity
No. of banks/financial institutions that agreed to finance CSH projects and CSH system component & equipment manufacturing as a result of the awareness enhancement programs by EOP
No. of papers presented in conference that were used by policy makers in decision making on technology applications, in general, and CSH technology applications, in particular
No of potential assessment studies done

actual.comment:
3 projects were commissioned. Thus the total number of projects installed is 26.
5 officials of Test Centers have been trained on testing of CSTs at 2 places namely Pune and Gurgaon on O & M of CSH systems.
Target met in 2014. Reported to UNDP through PIR 2014.
IREDA already has a provision for providing loans on solar thermal systems at normal interest rates and is applicable for CSTs.
An assignment “Organization of Training Programmes/Workshops for the Senior Officials of Banks/ FIs for the purpose of educating them to provide loans to the manufacturers and beneficiaries of CST based system” with the objective to ensure at least four banks/ FIs to provide loans to CSH systems has been awarded to PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) Pvt. Ltd., Gurgaon.
4 papers were presented during the reporting period.
1. Pankaj Kumar. Accelerating growth of CSTs in Industrial, Institutional and Commercial sectors. Workshop on Renewable Energy organised by Delhi Technical University on 18th June 2014
2. R P Goswami. MNRE Scheme on SWHS & CSTsInterSolar, Mumbai. 18 November 2014.
3. Pankaj Kumar. Market development and Promotion of CSTs for Industrial Application applications in India, The proceeding is available on the following link : http://conference.intersolar.de/cgi-bin/x-mkp/visitors/vac.pl?language=1&eve_id=23. Can be downloaded using a digit code 201418192011 on the link
4. Pankaj Kumar. Market development for Solar Concentrators in India. International Congress on Renewable Energy (ICORE) 2014 Workshop on “Powering National Growth Solar” organized by Solar Energy Society of India on 9th December 2014

result.title: Outcome 2.2
result.description:
CSH Project deliverables facilitated and/or influenced the widespread replication of CSH technology applications in India
Output 2.2.1: Documentations on the Project outputs, case studies, best practices and lessons learnt disseminated to ensure larger replication

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Cumulative number of e-newsletter issues prepared and disseminated by EOP
Cumulative number of quarterly magazines produced by EOP
No. of copies of each magazine issue circulated to CSH stakeholders (CSH system manufacturers, suppliers, importers, installers, maintenance service providers and users)starting year 1
Audio-visual capsule uploaded and accessible from project website
No. of users of the audio-visual capsule by the EOP
Project website established and operational
No. of CSH stakeholders that use the project website for information each year starting year 1
No. of brochures on CSH technology applications produced and disseminated by EOP
No. of copies of printed and disseminated compendium by EOP

actual.comment:

result.title: Output 2.1.7
result.description: Established Concentrating Solar Heat Technology Platform and is operational

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
An officially established CSH Technology Platform
Number of meetings conducted by the CSH Technology Platform by EOP
No. of CSH system users that make use of the platform in addressing issues/problems concerning energy performance and improvements of CSH systems by EOP
No. of CSH system manufacturers/suppliers/distributors that make use of the platform in addressing issues/problems concerning the market of CSH products by EOP

actual.comment:
A CSH platform was established during the reporting period. It comprises of key stakeholders from Government, Technical experts, Manufacturers, Consultants, International Organizations, NGOs, Test centres etc.
In addition CSTEAM, a manufacturer’s association was formed in 2013-14.
First meeting of CSH platform was held in April 2015 with a great enthusiasm among stakeholders. It is proposed to have such meeting on quarterly basis. In the first meeting, several issues were discussed.
1. Strengthen implementation – there are gaps in implementation and the CSH systems are unable to meet the claimed performance. [action by suppliers]
2. related to financing & implementation, Policy, Promotional activities etc.The major Issues are
3. Delay in inspection: Delay in inspection by state nodal agency have multiple impacts. Further there will be delay in releasing subsidies. This stress on working capital of suppliers. This spirals into lack of funds for further installations. [Action by MNRE]
4. Subsidy release on case to case basis: It was suggested MNRE release subsidy on case-to-case basis to avoid financial stress on suppliers.
5. Release the subsidy against bank guarantee: MNRE informed this requires modification in the scheme. [further exploration]
6. Issue guidelines to promote CSH systems. CREDA representative suggested that the guidelines to promote CSH systems should be issued to relevant government ministries such as HRD and Health Ministry. This can enable the government agencies to take up active participation and promotion of the technology in their respective establishments.
In addition 2 meetings of CSTEAM by the manufacturers and 2 others of experts/ manufacturers in MNRE were held in 2013-14 making a total of 5 such meetings held so far.
30 stakeholders participated in 1st CSH Platform meeting. In all 80 people participated, so far including of CSTEAM & other stakeholder interactions organized by MNRE.
Around 10 manufacturers participated in these meetings.

actual.comment:
Indian Renewable Energy Development Agency [IREDA] has provision for providing loans on Solar Thermal system at normal interest rates. This includes CSH systems.
Consultations are ongoing with banks/FIs to consider providing loans to CSH systems and also to formulate special lending packages for promote CSH systems. The target is to get a minimum of 4 banks/FIs commit to provide loans for CSH systems.
Software for assessing the economics of CST based systems has been developed during the reporting period.
ESCO is emerging as alternative financial option. PMU has presently approved a few projects. The actual learning will be available in subsequent years.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Update report on India's National Circumstances. 2. Prepare the Information of GHG inventory for India. 3. Increased accuracy of GHG inventory through the use of tier-III methodologies in multiple sectors. 4. Increase the accuracy of GHG inventory through the use of tier-III methodologies for most sectors. 5. Strengthened and streamlined National institutional structure for long term National GHG inventory and the estimation of GHG emissions. 6. Improve climate change projections with the use of advanced and updated Regional Climate Change models. 7. Make available and develop a clearer understanding of climate and socioeconomic scenarios for India. 8. Improve understanding of, and appropriate actions planned for addressing, vulnerability to climate change at different sectors and regions. 9. Increase understanding of Adaptation framework, measures and possible projects . 10. Increase understanding of GHG mitigation policies and measures at national and state level. 11. Increase understanding of gaps and constraints pertaining to financial, technical and capacity needs to address climate change. 12. Develop a Comprehensive description of systematic observations and research on climate change. 13. Enhance understanding of domestic mitigation actions, its need and the level/nature of support required, greenhouse gas emissions inventory and other related information.

GHG inventory are available as part of second national communication to UNFCCC developed in 2010 and submitted to UNFCCC in 2012 3. The existing national circumstances need to updated as per UNFCCC guidelines with latest information on national circumstances, 4. GHG inventory available for 2004- 2010 needs updating 5. Limited capacity of the National Institutional structure 6. Climate projections and GHG inventories currently in use in the country outdated, newer technologies need to be introduced 7. 2010 report available needs updating 8. 0 9. 2010 adaptation framework available needs updating 10. Limited understanding of GHG mitigation policies 11. Limited understanding of Gaps pertaining to financial technical and financial needs 12. There a few research and analysis available however require deeper research 13. Limited understanding of domestic mitigation actions and support required

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Impacts and vulnerability assessments, and adaptation measures

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
(A) Climate variability profiles & trends prepared at national & state level
(B) Climate change projections using latest CIMIP5 multiple GCM based outputs for different RCP scenarios at national & state level
(C) Quantitative impacts of climate change using latest models for different sectors such as (Water resource, agriculture, forest ecosystems, health, coastal zones etc.)
(D) Climate change vulnerability profiles developed at national &state level for different sectors
(E) Adaptation matrix for coping with climate impacts for different sectors and different regions
(F) Adaptation framework and policies for mainstreaming developed

baseline.comment:
(A) No state level climate variability profiles available
(B) Climate change projections are available only for SRES A2, B2 & A1B scenarios
(C) SNC presents climate impacts based on SRES scenarios
(D) Vulnerability profiles are not available for all the key sectors at national & state level
(E) Preliminary adaptation practices presented in SNC for only agriculture and forest sectors
(F) No adaptation framework presented in SNC and no national & state level adaptation framework & policies exist for mainstreaming adaptation in different sectors

target.comment:
(A) Climate variability profiles and maps prepared at state level
(B) Climate change projections and maps prepared based on multiple model ensemble based on CIMIP5 & RCP scenarios at GCM & RCM grid scales. Projections of extreme events made available
(C) Impacts of climate change on key sectors assessed using latest climate change projections for RCP scenarios and improved impact models
(D) Vulnerability profiles based on climatic, bio-physical & socio-economic factors developed
(E) Adaptation matrix developed for projected climate change impacts for different sectors at regional level and updated information for agriculture and forest sectors
(F) Policy framework developed for mainstreaming adaptation

actual.comment:
The first activity for this outcome was the consultation with experts on Impacts and vulnerability assessments, and adaptation measures. A National Workshop on Climate Change Impacts, Vulnerability and Adaptation was held in 2014.
A second workshop is being planned in September 2015
