indicator.description:
(A) Documentation and synthesis of national climate change policies.
(B) GHG emissions scenarios for 2020 and 2030
(C) Mitigation potential of Energy and Land use sectors and projections for 2020 and 2030 based on modelling
(D) Mitigation action plans at national and state levels
(E) Constraints, gaps and related technical, financial and capacity needs
(F) TNA and technology transfer and financial needs

baseline.comment:
(A) No such analysis is available, except a book published in 2004
(B) Ministry of Environment has published GHG emissions for 2030, which is outdated
(C)Mitigation potential not reported in SNC, but a few published papers available, which are based on limited information
(D) No national mitigation plan available apart from a Low Carbon strategy prepared by the Planning Commission. State level preliminary mitigation plans available for some states
(E) SNC
(F) SNC

target.comment:
(A) Climate change policy synthesis, analysis and implications described
(B)Improved model based GHG emissions projections developed
(C)Model based mitigation potential estimates for energy and land use sectors along with marginal abatement cost curves developed
(D) Sectoral mitigation options developed at national & state level along implications for GDP, employment, etc.
(E) Gaps and constraints analyzed and barriers are ranked using AHP methods
(F) Detailed TNA and technology transfer and financial needs assessed

actual.comment: Information is being updated for the TNC. First BUR is expected to present some of the initial findings.

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: Other information relevant for the preparation of the TNC – Comprehensive description of climate change research, strategies for sustainable National Communication process and communicating climate change to public

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
(A) Climate change research status and needs
(B) Financial and technical support for climate change related activities received from national and international sources
(C) Institutional arrangements for sustained National Communication process
(D) Stakeholder consultation and communicating climate change to different stakeholders

baseline.comment:
(A) SNC information until 2010
(B) No quantitative estimates available in SNC
(C) No institutional arrangement for long term and sustained preparation of national communication process presented in SNC
(D) Limited stakeholder consultation during SNC and no programs for communicating climate change

target.comment:
(A) Systematic and comprehensive plan for research and climate change along with estimation of financial resources
(B) Report on the financial flows into climate change activities from national and international sources
(C) Institutional arrangements with roles and responsibilities and financial and technical resource needs assessed and made available
(D) Mechanisms and institutional arrangements made and implemented for communicating climate change to stakeholder and public

actual.comment: Information is being updated for the TNC. First BUR is expected to present some of the initial findings.

result.title: Outcome 6
result.description: Third National Communication Report Preparation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
(A) Reporting of the outcomes of the National Communication process on the NATCOM website, along with GHG inventories, climate change projection and impact and vulnerability maps
(B) Publication / printing of the TNC
(C) Summary Report of the National Communication translated in major languages of India
(D) Periodic technical reports on climate change projections, impacts and vulnerability assessments (E) Final evaluation report

baseline.comment:

(B) SNC published and shared with the public and stakeholders
(C) So far no summaries has been published in major Indian languages
(D) A few technical reports published during the preparation of SNC
(E) Final evaluation report of SNC completed

target.comment:
(A)All information relevant to preparation of TNC published on the NATCOM website
(B) TNC finalized and presented to Government of India and report published after approval
(C) Summary and key findings of the TNC published in major India languages
(D) Periodic technical reports, book and journal articles published

actual.comment: Information on impacts and vulnerability assessments is being updated. First BUR is expected to present some of the initial findings.

result.title: Outcome 7
result.description: Enhanced understanding of domestic mitigation actions and preparation of Biennial Update Reports for submission during 2014, 2016 and 2018

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
(A) Biennial update of GHG inventory for the years 2010 and 2012
(B) Update of the national circumstances and institutional arrangements from BUR perspective for 2014 and 2016
(C) Mitigation actions and their effects until 2020, including associated assumptions, methodologies and modeling
(D) Update on the technical, financial capacity needs and support received for implementing these mitigation actions
(E) Biennial Update Reports (BUR) submitted in 2014 and 2016

baseline.comment:
(A) No previous reports other than SNC reporting GHG inventory for year 2000
(B) Only SNC report
(C) No previous reports
(D) Only SNC
(E) Only SNC

target.comment:
(A) BUR for 2014, 2016 and 2018
(B) BUR for 2014, 2016 and 2018
(C) BUR for 2014, 2016 and 2018
(D) BUR for 2014, 2016 and 2018
(E) BUR for 2014, 2016 and 2018

actual.comment: First Biennial Update report has been prepared and subjected to independent review. After consideration of comments from experts, the draft of first BUR was subjected to the Expert Advisory Committee on BUR that endorsed the document on 24 April 2015 with little changes. The report was placed to the meeting of National Steering Committee on 30 April 2015 where the report was duly agreed upon for submission. After taking NSC comments into consideration a revised draft was prepared along with the draft cabinet note, which was approved by the minister. The draft cabinet note and the draft BUR thus prepared has been circulated to ministries for comments and feedback. After the comment period is over, a final cabinet note will be placed for consideration of the cabinet. After approval, the BUR will be submitted to the UNFCCC.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Develop the Capacity of the Health Care sector to Neo Natal and Maternal Health on Home based Neonatal Care Plus (HBNC+) by provision of training health care providers 2) Number of health care providers trained in providing supportive supervision under HBNC+ 3) Number of infants visited under the HBNC+ 4) Availability of Skilled Health Care Workers on Sick New Born Neonatal Care Units 5)Develop and establish a Monitoring and evaluation system for the NIPI new born project 6) Availability of training materials/manual/guidelines/ resource centers on HBNC+ 7) Number of assessment undertaken to assess quality of pediatric care in district hospitals

target.comment: 1) Train 19,000 Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) on HBNC+ 2) Train 700 ASHA supervisors on Supportive Supervision under HBNC+ 3) Visit 1,25,000 infants under HBNC+ 4) Train 10,000 ASHA and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) under SNCU+ 5) Establish a Monitoring and Evaluation system for the NIPI new born project 6) Ensure 8 resource centres provide supportive supervision for new born care 7) Undertake an assessment of the quality of paediatric care in 13 district hospitals

actual.comment: 1) 20,327 ASHA trained on HBNC+ 2) 856 ASHA supervisors trained on Supportive Supervision under HBNC+ 3) 1,34,887 infants visited under HBNC+ 4) 10,272 ASHA and ANM trained under SNCU+ 5) Web based Monitoring and Evaluation system established in 13 project districts of 4 states. 6) 8 resource centers established for providing supportive supervision for new born care 7) Assessment conducted for the quality of pediatric care in 13 district hospitals, report printed and disseminated.

target.comment: 1) 70,000 infants receive incentive for completing 4 visits under HBNC+ 2) 3,00,000 infants receive at least one home visit under HBNC+ 3) 10,000 visits for supportive supervision undertaken for HBNC+ 4) Undertake the Training of Trainers for Emergency Triage and Treatment (ETAT) and Family Centric Care (FCC) in 5 district hospitals. 5) Undertake Evaluation of the HBNC+ initiated through external agency 6) Conduct of periodic assessment in 13 districts. 7) Development of operational guidelines for pediatric care in district hospitals

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Number of States using web based Monitoring System to report on Forest Right Acts 2) Number of capacity tools such as traning manuals and knowledge products developed 3) Number of centres for excellence established on tribal development 4) Number of Forest dwelling communities access right to land and forest produce 5) Develop Institutional mechanism and operational tools to help states plan, implement and monitor TSP based on tribal communities’ needs 6) Prepare the National Tribal HDR on inclusive growth 7) Develop the National Skill building strategy for tribal communities will be prepared 8) Demonstrate Community-led model on forest resource management for conservation and livelihood generation will be demonstrated

target.comment: (1) Design a Web-based monitoring system for reporting by states on FRA implementation (2) Develop 3 Training manuals for Gram Sabhas, Elected Representatives, Revenue and Forest Officials and Committees under FRA to implement and monitor the Act (3) Establish one centre for excellence on tribal development (4) Ensure 30,000 claims filed and 15,000 recognised under the Forest Rights Act (5) Develop Institutional mechanism and operational tools to help states plan, implement and monitor TSP based on tribal communities’ needs (6) Prepare the National Tribal HDR on inclusive growth (7) Develop the National Skill building strategy for tribal communities (8) Demonstrate a Community-led model on forest resource management for conservation and livelihood generation

actual.comment:
(1) Web based Monitoring conceptual framework developed (2) 2 trainings manuals on Role of Government Functionaries and Civil Society Organisations developed (3) National resource centre on Forest Rights Act established in Odisha for capacity building, research and innovation on tribal issues (4) Maharashtra and Odisha recorded an increase filing of claims by forest dwelling communities (45896 claims field and 17201 recognition of titles) (5) TSP operational guidelines developed (6) Linear Papers to feed into the Tribal HDR commissioned (7) National Consultation on skills organised to address needs of tribal communities for sustainable livelihoods held. This will lead to the draft strategy (8) Demonstrated Community-led model on forest resource management for conservation and livelihood generation
Other Results (9) International exposure visit and cross learning amongst States with substantial tribal population led to – increased recognition of individual and community rights under FRA, projects proposals from states on tribal development more responsive and contextualized to tribal needs (10) Supported roll out of Van Bandhu Kalyan Yojana (VKY) on pilot basis in 10 blocks in 10 Schedule V states with low HDI (11) Inter-ministerial dialogue and coordination facilitated for integration of the tribal agenda, particularly on the issues of health and livelihood

target.comment: Forest Right Act (FRA) (1) Pilot the Web-based Monitoring System, an e-governance and accountability tool for reporting by states on FRA Implementation (2) Develop Training manuals for Gram Sabhas, Elected Representatives, Revenue and Forest Officials to implement and monitor FRA prepared & disseminated to states (3) Establish a Technical unit at National Resource Centre (NRC) to provide technical and handholding support to states (4) Another 50,000 more claims be filed and realisation of 25,000 happen (5) Compile ‘Land mark judgments on FRA‘ and ‘directive/direction issued by MoTA & states’ as an ready reckoner Van Bhandhu Kalyan Yojana (VKY) (6) support the scale up VKY in the entire country to improve infrastructure and HD indices of the tribal population (7) Develop Tools and mechanisms to design VKY to make them more coherent and relevant to tribal needs through convergence of resources developed (8) Demonstrate an Innovation Hub on tribal livelihood and health supported in cluster of village Tribal Human Development Report (9) National Tribal HDR on inclusive growth prepared Community Mobilization (10) Community models with participatory livelihood and NRM in 4 states in cluster of 10 villages each on pilot basis, field tested and disseminated through field visit

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of Fellowship opportunities offered to mid-career and young professionals 2. Number of countries supported every year for review of NHDRs in Asia Pacific 3. Number of South South International collaborative workshops on human development related themes

target.comment: 1. Award Human Development Fellowships 2. Provide Technical advisory services to be provided for countries in Asia Pacific for preparation of National Human Development report 3. Facilitate South-South cooperation through training and workshops for capacity development organized

actual.comment: 1. 7 professionals from Africa, the Arab States and Asia-Pacific were awarded the Human Development Residential Fellowships at IIAS, Shimla 2. 8 countries in Asia–Pacific were provided technical advisory services relating to the preparation of National Human Development Reports (NHDRs). Five of these NHDRs were launched in 2014. 3. 3 capacity development initiatives organized: 25 participants from 7 SAARC countries participated in a study week on ‘Accelerating Progress on SAARC Development Goals’; 30 participants from 9 countries of South Asia participated in a webinar on communication and dissemination for HDRs; 20 participants from India participated in an interactive dialogue on writing readable reports

target.comment: 1. Award Human Development Fellowships 2. Provide Technical advisory services to be provided for countries in Asia Pacific for preparation of National Human Development report 3. Facilitate South-South cooperation through training and workshops for capacity development organized

actual.comment: 1. 3 young professional and 1 mid-career professional awarded human development fellowship, policy papers submitted are under review 2. 2capacity development workshops conducted: Workshop on Making a Difference: Youth and Human Development organized for 14 young change makers from 6 countries in Asia and Workshop on open data for human development conducted for participants from India and Bhutan 3. Round table discussing Direct Benefits and Basic income transfers organized to inform policymaking

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1 Develop the strategy for difficult districts derived from the learning of strengthening effectiveness of ministry programmes in focus districts ready for wider replication by the Government of India. 2.Number of States that will be able to design, implement and monitor specific strategies for inclusion of persistently excluded groups in livelihood programmes. 3. Number of State governments will have systems, mechanisms and tools for improved efficiency, accountability and inclusiveness of MGNREGP and NRLM. 4. Number of guidelines, mechanisms and manuals developed for the Ministry of Rural Development (MoRDeto support promotion and monitoring of green results in select schemes such as MGNREGP, IAY and PMGSY. 5. Number states that have the comprehensive annual action plans approved by NRLM and Aajeevika Skills

baseline.comment: 1. No strategy available for difficult districts 2. 0 3. 0 4. 0 5. 0

target.comment: 1. Identify and ensure roll out in the Focus districts to include strategy, implementation plan, monitoring systems and human resource in place, in partnership with the state governments. 2. 4 states develop special plans for inclusion of excluded 2 of the 5 (five) groups identified 3. Ensure availability of tools and resources for efficient and effective implementation of MGNREGS 4. Undertake Green audit of the IAY, MGNREGS and PMGSY available with Ministry of Rural Development; and tools & methodologies provided for IAY and MGNREGS Ministry of Rural Development 5. Twenty nine (29) state-level comprehensive Annual Action Plans approved by NRLM and 7 state action plans for Aajeevika Skills supported;

actual.comment: 1. Roll out in the focus districts has been intiated including depolyment of Human resources. Studies on Non Timber Forest Products (NTFP) and Financial Inclusion for the Focus Districts have been completed and reports shared with the Ministry of Rural Development. 2. 4 states developed special plans for 5 groups have been developed and pilots initiated for Persons with Disabilities (PwDs), Trafficked women and Manual Scavengers.5 projects for building enterprises with the communities as primary movers developed and submitted to National Rural Livelihoo Mission (NRLM) for support which are based on NTFP such as lac, gum, medicinal plants; involving over 30,000 tribal women directly; involving PVTGs such as Paudi Bhuyan, the Juang, the Choktia bhunjia, Kondhs, Bhagtas, Porjas and Kotias. 3. Developed 7 guidelines, 8 manuals, 2 Advisories, Action Plan, Circular, Discussion note, Norms, Directives, Order, Estimation & field trials for MGNREGA works and MIS supported for effective implementation of MGNREGS and being used by the states. This was done by 19 Experts were placed wtihin the Ministry and the State Governments of Chhattisgarh and Bihar. 4. A Green Task Force set up and functioning within MoRD; 5 compendiums of alternative building technologies in different states ready for inclusion under IAY; Alternative designs for housing under IAY approved and ready for adoption in Tripura. Capacities of 6 CSO resource agencies (and communities through them) built for development of green perspective plans under MGNREGS. Four of the CSOs have been appointed as Cluster Facilitation Teams for MGNRE 5.. 29 (28 state and 1 UT) state-level AAPs under NRLM supported for approval; NRLM & Aajeevika Skills supported for initiation in the north-eastern states. 25 State Plans supported for approval under Aajeevika Skills. Development of a number of systems supported and put in place for efficient implementation of Aajeevika Skills .A ” Knowledge Management Repository” created on

target.comment: 1. Complete the roll out in Focus Districts component with strategy, implementation plan, monitoring systems and human resource in place in consultation with state governments.. 2. 4 states Develop Strategies & Protocols for addressing vulnerabilities of the poor in the excluded gropus indentified 3. Ensure Tools and resources for efficient and effective implementation of MGNREGS developed. 4. Ensure Preparation, Appraisal and Approval of 29 comprehensive Annual Action Plans by SRLMs to implement NRLM and 7 state action plans for Aajeevika Skills supported; and measures for increasing efficiency in implementation provided 5. Undertake Green audit of the IAY, MGNREGS and PMGSY available with MoRD; and tools & methodologies provided for IAY and MGNREGS

indicator.description: 1. Number of technical officers provided to the Ministry on specific domains namely institutional development, panchayat finance, NRM, Mobilisation to increase the capacity of Ministry of Panchayati Raj 2. Number resource material, manuals and knowledge products developed in priority areas of the Ministry of Panchayati Raj 3. Number of Resource material developed to mobilised gram sabhas in schedule V areas

baseline.comment: 1. 0 2. Very few resouce material available on the issues of panchayat finance, natural resource management, social sector, women and child, mobilisation and institutional development in the context of panchayats 3. 0

target.comment: 1. Provide Technical assistance via the placement of 6 technical officers to the RGPSA (Rajiv Gandhi Panchayat Sashaktikaran Abhiyan) unit of the Ministry of Panchayati Raj 2. Develop resource material and training module for use by panchayats for select themes 3. Develop Resource material on mobilizing gram sabhas in Schedule V Areas

actual.comment: 1. A team of six technical officers provided to the Ministry of Panchayati Raj in the following thematic areas - institutional development, panchayat finance, natural resource management, mobilisation, functions and processes; and social sectors. 2. Three resource books in sanitation, water and local governance finalised and released. One of these was prepared entirely by the technical team, while the other two were anchored with resource institution with very strong support provided by the technical team. The resource material is being adapted in around 10 states. These are part of an Active Panchayat Series that will have more publications. 3. Preparation of a resource book on mobilisaing gram sabha initiated.

target.comment: 1. indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of Marginalized individuals and community groups with increased Access to justice and entitlements under government programmes 2. The National Mission on Justice Delivery has the requisite technical and implementation capacity to reduce pendency in courts 3. Mainstream Legal Literacy through various Government Schemes 4. Number of studies and assessments conducted to provide policy recommendations to judiciary on making court rooms women friendly

baseline.comment: 1.There is very little or no data available to ascertain the number of marginalized groups accessing justice and entitlements under the Government Programmes 2. There is high pendency in courts which amounts to almost 2.5 Million cases in 2013 3. 0 4. 0

target.comment: 1. 3 State Legal Services Authorities have trained panel lawyers and trained paralegals. 2. National Mission on Justice Delivery and Legal Reforms provided technical assistance for making policy recommendations to the judiciary on pendency reduction 3. Legal literacy content mainstreamed and disseminated through Sakshar Bharat, SIRDs, voice based legal information kiosks and law schools 4. Fresh evidence gathered to provide policy recommendations to judiciary on making court-rooms women-friendly, issues of under-trials, and juvenile justice.

actual.comment: 1. Seven trainings and four refresher trainings for 278 paralegal volunteers was conducted in the 2 states of Orissa and Madhya Pradesh. UNDP developed the Final draft of facilitator’s guide that was shared with NALSA. The panel Lawyers Training of 85 Lawyers and did the refresher training of 65 Panel Lawyers of 5 districts of Orissa. 100 Panel Lawyers in Madhya Pradesh and 10 young lawyers were selected as UNVs and placed with Legal Services Authorities in Orissa. 2. Regular technical assistance at the Ministry was provided to National Mission on Justice Delivery and Legal Reforms via technical experts placed there as well as research, assessments and reviews 3. legal literacy was mainstreamed by the establishment of 50 voice based legal information kiosks (25 at one state each) at the selected locations in Chhattisgarh and Jharkhand. 36185 persons accessed kiosks for various legal information during 2014 in Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh 4. A study on women friendly procedures in fast track courts of Delhi was commissioned with the objective to make recommendations for improved court room procedures for rape victims.

target.comment: 1. 2 more States and States Legal Services Authority (SALSA) have trained panel lawyers and trained paralegals 2. Develop and implement a Management Information System to reduce pendency in courts 3. Legal literacy content mainstreamed and disseminated through Sakshar Bharat, SIRDs, voice based legal information kiosks and law schools scaled up in further states 4. Compete and disseminate findings of the study for improved court room procedures for rape victims

iati-activity.title: India High Range Landscape
iati-activity.description: Developing an effective multiple-use management framework for conserving biodiversity in the mountain landscape of the High Ranges, the Western Ghats, India.

iati-activity.title: India High Range Landscape
iati-activity.description: Developing an effective multiple-use management framework for conserving biodiversity in the mountain landscape of the High Ranges, the Western Ghats, India.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To protect biodiversity of the High Range Mountain Landscape of the southern Western Ghats in peninsular India from existing and emergent threats through building an effective collaborative governance framework for multiple use management.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Extent brought under multiple use management planning framework

baseline.comment: 0 ha

actual.comment: This project covers an area of 3000 ,000 ha in the landscape. Studies have been commissioned to review the sectoral planning and governance system in the landscape. The data gathered in the first two years of the project will provide the basis for developing a collaborative framework on multiple-use management of this landscape.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Population status of following critical species remain stable or increases:
Nilgiri tahr
Grizzled giant squirrel
Tiger

target.comment: Remain stable or increases by project end

actual.comment:
Periodic wildlife estimation are done by the State Forest Department.
Nilgiri tahr estimation done in March 2015 indicates a population of 900 in the project area.
Estimated population of Grizzled Giant Squirrel (GGS) during 2013-14 in Chinnar WLS indicates 24.42 individuals/km2. Since the methodology used during baseline survey and the recent estimates are different (total count method vs density estimates through transect method), the figures could not be compared. However, the population of GGS remains stable in Chinnar WLS.
Tiger estimation done in Nov 2014 indicates a total population of 136 tigers in the State which is shown to be a substantial increase in the population (the estimated population of tigers in the State during 2010 is 71). Landscape-level estimation carried out in 2010 has not been attempted in 2014, hence exact figures of tigers in the landscape cannot be given.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Percentage increase in habitats categorized as high conservation value over the baseline.

baseline.comment:
PA: 207.5 km2
Non-PAs: 846 km2

target.comment:
10% increase by mid-term and 20 % by project end.
10 % increase by mid-term and 15% by project end

actual.comment: Due to opposition to the project, only preparatory activities such as baseline assessments and studies were carried out. Identification of high conservation value areas will be initiated in the next reporting period.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Improvements in water quality in the water bodies of the landscape

baseline.comment: BOD -1.5 mg/l at Neriamangalamand 1.4 mg/l at Bhoothathankett

target.comment: 10% improvement by project end.

actual.comment: Study has been commissioned to assess the current quality of the water in the water bodies in the landscape. The study is also identifying good practices including traditional practices in water conservation in the state. Interventions from project will be decided by the Technical Commitee based on the recommendations emanating from this study.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Effective governance framework for multiple-use mountain landscape management in place

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Landscape Level Land use Plan (LLLUP) developed adhering to multiple use management decisions

actual.comment: Baseline studies have been commissioned to review sectoral plans and gather data which will help design the governance framework for a multiple- landuse landscape. this is a new area of work and there is very little experience in the country for this purpose. The project is seeking guidance from other projects of similar nature in the country to learn and adapt.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Sector-specific biodiversity-plans compatible with LLLUP developed leading to effective integration of biodiversity considerations into production practices

target.comment: At least six Sector Plans (Forestry, Tourism, Tea, Cardamom, Agriculture and Tribal Development) and Biodiversity Conservation Plans (5) in place

actual.comment: Studies will be commissioned in year two to ascertain the opportunities within the sectoral plans to incorporate biodiversity friendly practices and principles in sectoral plans and also align these with the Landscape level plan..

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Effective and functioning cross-sectoral, multi-stakeholder institution (including conservation, livelihood and production) established.

actual.comment: The project envisages the establishment of a multi-stakeholder institution with representation from all relevant sectors. An appraisal will be done of the different models of governance institutions in the country and based on the recommendations of this appraisal, the State will decide on teh nature of the institution. Presently, a Working Committee has been formed under the Chairmanship of the Addiitional Chief Secretary in the State which has representation of officials from all line departments and other relevant stakeholders.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of key policy and management framework/ decisions adopted at local and state level related to sustainable mountain landscape management

target.comment: 7 (Wildlife Protection Act, Forest Conservation Act, Environment Protection Act, Forest Rights Act, Cardamom Rules, KDH Act, Land Assignment Act, Commodities Act), National Working Plan Code and other Management decisions

actual.comment: The project will commission a study in year 2 to review in details all legal and policy matters related to the objective of the project. Field activities and demonstration interventions will inform relevant policies.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Improvement in Systemic Level Indicators of Capacity Development Scorecard (Annex 19)

baseline.comment:
1. Capacity to conceptualize and formulate policies, legislations, strategies, programme 40%
2. Capacity to implement policies, legislation, strategies and programmes 33%
3. Capacity to engage and build consensus among all stakeholders 15%
4. Capacity to mobilize information and knowledge 35%
5. Capacity to monitor, evaluate and report and learn at the sector and project levels. 30%

target.comment:
1. Capacity to conceptualize and formulate policies, legislations, strategies, programme 80%
2. Capacity to implement policies, legislation, strategies and programmes 80%
3. Capacity to engage and build consensus among all stakeholders 15% 80%
4. Capacity to mobilize information and knowledge 35% 80%
5. Capacity to monitor, evaluate and report and learn at the sector and project levels. 30% 80%

actual.comment: A capacity assessment framework will be developed in year 2 which will guage the current capacities and develop a capacity deveelopment plan for all relevant stakeholders. Presently, two institutions have been engaged, Kerala Institute of Local Administration (KILA), a govt. institution and MYRADA, a NGO for this purpose.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Multiple use mountain landscape management is applied securing the ecological integrity of HRML

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Improved management effectiveness PAs as measured and recorded by Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METT)

baseline.comment: 168 out of 300

target.comment:
Increase in METT scores by 10 percent by year 3
By 20 percent by year 5

actual.comment: The Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool has not been exercised during this period. This indicator will be assessed only at the 3rd and 5th year as the project is yet to start in the field. Hence, this indicator cannot be considered at this stage.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Increase in area under PA system

target.comment: Increase by 11,500 ha

actual.comment: There are apprehensions in the project area among several stakeholders particularly with regard to exapnsion of Protected Areas and enforcing regulations and infringing the rights of the stakeholders. This indicator needs to be deleted.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Areas of forest fragments/ HVBAs in tea gardens inventoried and secured

actual.comment: Study will be commissioned in year 2

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: % reduction in fuel wood consumption for processing in tea and cardamom using energy efficient technology and improved design (indicator, baselines and targets will have to be re-visited once the Sector Plans are prepared by mid-term)

baseline.comment: Baseline to be measured in 1st 3 months of project

target.comment: 10% decline over baseline usage and 20% in cardamom

actual.comment: A Study has been commissioned to know the base line and to explore the best practices available in the country.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of new demonstration programmes/ featuring biodiversity friendly production practices (e.g. curing units/ energy efficiency options/ farming practices) adopted

actual.comment: Agencies engaged to explore the best practices. Pilot implementation will be done in due course of time.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Strengthened community capacities for community based sustainable use and management of wild resources

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of development plans of PRIs/ CBOs that incorporate bio-diversity friendly practices

actual.comment: Study has been commissioned with MYRADA, NGO working in South India with the PRIs in enhancing capacities of PRIs, reviewing the current micro development plans and identifying opportunities for greening the plans.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of community representatives/ PRIs trained in biodiversity mainstreaming activities

actual.comment: Material is being prepared by Kerala State Biodiversity Board (KSBB) and Kerala Institute of Local Administration (KILA); organised capacity building activities will begin in year 3.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of new micro-enterprises at individual/SHG/ CBO/ and other local institution levels based sustainable resource use

target.comment: Target to be defined after design of the micro-plans

actual.comment: Agency engaged to identify livelihood options available in the landscape. Pilot implementation will be done in due course of time.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: % reduction in biomass consumption in lemon grass enterprises through adoption of improved technology.

baseline.comment: 494,361 kg/ year

target.comment: 10 percent reduction by 3rd year and 20 percent by project end.

actual.comment: Agency would be engaged to identify the best practices and then pilot implementation will be done

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Appropriate model agreement between different agencies on the effective implementation of FRA as evidence through sustainable use and protection of biodiversity in Edamalakudy Panchayat

actual.comment: This component of Forest Rights Act (FRA) will be included in the assignment given to Kerala Institute of Local Administration, a government institute mandated to build capacities of institutes of local self governance.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Develop training material in the areas of coastal and marine biodiversity conservation to be included as an elective in the curriculum of India Forest Service being trained in the Indira Gandhi National Forest Academy 2. Number of forest officers trained in the elective package 3. Review and Revision of the National Forest Policy of 1988 4. Resource Mobilization Strategy for achieving the national biodiversity targets 5. Tools and techniques developed for establishing participatory ground water management in the project areas, to be adapted by the Niranchal Programme 6. Develop a document on best practices on biodiversity governance

target.comment: 1) Develop Two training manuals on coastal and biodiversity 2) Train 30 Forest Offciers on the elective modules 3) Undertake the review the forest policy of India 1958 4) Develop the resource mobilisation strategy for achieving the national biodiversity targets 5) Develop a methodology to carry out a situational analysis in ground water management at project sites 6) Documentnt good examples of biodiversity governance for sharing at national and international fora

actual.comment: 1) UNP developed 2 training maualP facilitated in the preparation of course curriculum for probationers of the Indian Forest Service under the aegis of IGNFA with support from national experts 2) 30 Forest Officers completed their training on the elective modules 3) Forest Policy review scheduled in 2015 4) Resouce Mobilisation strategy scheduled in 2015 5) Methodology to carry out the situational analysis developed, the methodology was used to carry out the situational analysis in project sites 6) Documentation of 150 cases of good governance collected, 12 were awarded by the Governer of Andaman and Nicobar Islands

target.comment: 1) The training manuals on coastal and biodiversity adapted by a further 3 institution in the country 2) Train another 30 Forest Offciers on the elective modules 3) Undertake the review the forest policy of India 1958 4) Develop the resource mobilisation strategy for achieving the national biodiversity targets 5) Conducted Situational Analysis in the 18 project districts and capacity building plans developed for state and district level 6) Publish the best practise document and develop 5 films based on the case districts

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Number of states that implement the electronic vaccine intelligence network (eVIN) 2) Number of Government Staff trained on the use of web and mobile based application for vaccine logistic management 3) Number of cold chain points equipped with temperature monitoring loggers

target.comment: 1. Undertake the preparatory assessment of all districts of three state i.e. 165, with more that 5000 cold chain points 2. Develop and advertise the Terms of Reference for HR deployment, Capacity Building, Software for training Government Staff 3. Finalise the terms of reference for temperature monitoring loggers for cold chain points

actual.comment: 1. The Preparatory Assessment of all districts in 3 states of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan completed 2. Terms of Reference finalized and agency (s) to undertake the trainings finalised 3. Terms of Reference and specifications for the procurement of temperature loggers completed and advertised. Selection of agency is still underway

target.comment: 1. Roll out the web based Vaccine Logistic and Cold Chain Management solution in at least 40% of all districts of the 3 states of Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh 2. Complete Human Resource Deployment at the state and district level of MP, UP and Rajasthan and train 1,000 Government Staff 3. Install and operate at least 1,000 temperature loggers catering to 500 cold chain points
